question:
This question refers to the following information.
"The Romanists have, with great adroitness, drawn three walls round themselves, with which they have hitherto protected themselves, so that no one could reform them, whereby all Christendom has fallen terribly.
Firstly, if pressed by the temporal power, they have affirmed and maintained that the temporal power has no jurisdiction over them, but, on the contrary, that the spiritual power is above the temporal.
Secondly, if it were proposed to admonish them with the Scriptures, they objected that no one may interpret the Scriptures but the Pope.
Thirdly, if they are threatened with a council, they pretend that no one may call a council but the Pope…
…The second wall is even more tottering and weak: that they alone pretend to be considered masters of the Scriptures; although they learn nothing of them all their life. They assume authority, and juggle before us with impudent words, saying that the Pope cannot err in matters of faith, whether he be evil or good, albeit they cannot prove it by a single letter. That is why the canon law contains so many heretical and unchristian, nay unnatural, laws; but of these we need not speak now. For whereas they imagine the Holy Ghost never leaves them, however unlearned and wicked they may be, they grow bold enough to decree whatever they like. But were this true, where were the need and use of the Holy Scriptures? Let us burn them, and content ourselves with the unlearned gentlemen at Rome, in whom the Holy Ghost dwells, who, however, can dwell in pious souls only. If I had not read it, I could never have believed that the devil should have put forth such follies at Rome and find a following."
Martin Luther, Address to the Nobility of the German Nation, 1520
When the author of the passage above discusses the "second wall," to what is he referring? (A) The differing views of Catholics and Reformers on the appropriate use and interpretation of biblical texts (B) The differing views of Catholics and Reformers on the appropriate method of baptism
pred:
The answer to the question is (A) The differing views of Catholics and Reformers on the appropriate use and interpretation of biblical texts.

Explanation:
In the passage, Martin Luther discusses the "second wall" as the claim by Romanists (Catholics) that they alone have the authority to interpret the Scriptures. Luther criticizes this assertion, arguing that it is arrogant and incorrect. He points out that the Romanists, despite claiming a monopoly on scriptural interpretation, do not actually learn from the Scriptures throughout their lives. Luther further asserts that the Pope, regardless of his moral character (evil or good), is claimed to be infallible in matters of faith by the Romanists. This claim, Luther argues, is unsubstantiated and leads to the creation of canon law that includes heretical and unchristian principles. Luther's critique highlights the tension between the Catholic Church's claim of exclusive scriptural interpretation authority and the Reformers' belief in the accessibility and interpretability of Scripture by all believers. This difference in views on the use and interpretation of biblical texts is central to the theological disputes of the Reformation period.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
"My little homestead in the city, which I recently insured for ￡2,000 would no doubt have shared the common fate, as the insurance companies will not make good that which is destroyed by the Queen's enemies. And although I have a farm of 50 acres close to the town, no doubt the crops and premises would have been destroyed. In fact, this has already partly been the case, and I am now suing the Government for damages done by a contingent of 1,500 natives that have recently encamped not many hundred yards from the place, who have done much damage all around."
Letter from a British citizen to his sister during the Anglo-Zulu War, South Africa, 1879
The inclusion of the author's pending litigation with the British government serves to do which of the following? (A) Place blame on both his home country as well as the Zulus (B) Express his opposition to the ongoing war
pred: The inclusion of the author's pending litigation with the British government serves to express his opposition to the ongoing war. By mentioning his lawsuit against the government for damages caused by the Zulu contingent, the author is highlighting the negative impact of the war on his personal property and livelihood. This implies that he is not only concerned about the material loss but also critical of the government's actions and the broader conflict, suggesting a stance against the war and its consequences.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
Every two months His Majesty sends from Lima 60,000 pesos to pay for the mita of the Indians. Up on the Huanacavelica range there are 3,000 or 4,000 Indians working in the mercury mine, with picks and hammers, breaking up the ore. And when they have filled up their little sacks, the poor fellows, loaded down, climb up those ladders and rigging, so distressing that a man can hardly get up them. That is the way they work in this mine, with many lights and the loud noise of the pounding and great confusion. Nor is that the greatest evil; that is due to thievish and undisciplined superintendents. According to His Majesty's warrant, the mine owners at Potosí have a right to the mita of 13,300 Indians. These mita Indians earn each day 4 reals. Besides these there are others not under obligation, who hire themselves out voluntarily: these each get from 12 to 16 reals, and some up to 24, according to how well they wield their picks or their reputation for knowing how to get the ore out.
Antonio Vasquez de Espinosa, report on mining in Huanacavelica and Potosí, 1620s
The third principal reason the local Yakut and Tungus natives are ruined is that from the time they first came under Russian control, they have been forced to pay yasak tribute. Some have paid in sables, others in red foxes, still others in cash. At first there were plenty of furbearing animals there, but now there are no sables and not many foxes in those lands, from the shores of the Arctic Ocean all the way south to the great Lena River. Moreover, almost half the natives cannot hunt because they no longer have horses, many of which have been pawned to the yasak collectors.
Heinrich von Füch, "On the Treatment of Natives in Northeast Siberia," 1744
According to the second passage, which of the following contributed most to the burden faced by native Siberians attempting to fulfill their tribute obligations? (A) Overhunting and depletion of furbearing animals (B) Competition from Russian hunters and trappers
pred:
The second passage by Heinrich von Füch describes the third principal reason the local Yakut and Tungus natives are ruined, which is the yasak tribute they have been forced to pay since coming under Russian control. This tribute has caused significant hardship for the natives.

The main factor contributing to the burden faced by the native Siberians attempting to fulfill their tribute obligations is:

(A) Overhunting and depletion of furbearing animals

This is because the passage states that the natives have been forced to pay tribute in furbearing animals such as sables and foxes. As these animals have become scarce due to overhunting and other factors, it has become increasingly difficult for the natives to meet their tribute obligations. The passage mentions that "now there are no sables and not many foxes in those lands," indicating a severe depletion of these animals, which directly impacts the natives' ability to pay the tribute. 

The other options do not directly relate to the passage's explanation of the natives' plight:

(B) Competition from Russian hunters and trappers - While competition from Russian hunters and trappers could indirectly contribute to the scarcity of furbearing animals, the passage does not explicitly state this as the primary reason for the natives' difficulties in fulfilling their tribute obligations.

(C) Loss of horses - Although the loss of horses is mentioned as a separate issue (many have been pawned to yasak collectors), it is not the main factor highlighted in the passage for the natives' burden in paying tribute. The passage focuses on the scarcity of furbearing animals as the primary issue.

Therefore, the answer to the question is (A) Overhunting and depletion of furbearing animals.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
"Let a woman retire late to bed, but rise early to duties; let her nor dread tasks by day or by night. Let her not refuse to perform domestic duties whether easy or difficult. That which must be done, let her finish completely, tidily, and systematically, When a woman follows such rules as these, then she may be said to be industrious.
Let a woman be correct in manner and upright in character in order to serve her husband. Let her live in purity and quietness of spirit, and attend to her own affairs. Let her love not gossip and silly laughter. Let her cleanse and purify and arrange in order the wine and the food for the offerings to the ancestors. When a woman observes such principles as these, then she may be said to continue ancestral worship.
No woman who observes these three fundamentals of life has ever had a bad reputation or has fallen into disgrace. If a woman fail to observe them, how can her name be honored; how can she but bring disgrace upon herself?"
© The East Asian Library and the Gest Collection, Princeton University.
Ban Zhao, Lessons for a Woman, ca. 80 C.E.
In what way were women's lives in the period 600 B.C.E. to 600 C.E. generally more restricted than women's lives had been globally before the advent of sedentary societies? (A) Women's power increasingly fell within the private sphere. (B) Women's power increasingly fell within the public sphere.
pred:
The passage from Ban Zhao's "Lessons for a Woman" outlines the expected behaviors and roles of women in Chinese society during the Han Dynasty (206 BCE – 220 CE), which falls within the broader period of 600 BCE to 600 CE. This period saw significant changes in the structure of societies worldwide, including the development of more complex, sedentary, and hierarchical societies.

In the context of this passage, women's lives were generally more restricted in several key ways compared to the lives of women in pre-sedentary societies:

1. **Private Sphere Dominance**: The passage emphasizes that a woman's power and influence were to be confined to the private sphere, particularly within the home and in her duties to her husband and family. This is a clear indication that women's roles became more restricted and confined to domestic responsibilities. This contrasts with some pre-sedentary societies where women might have held more public and communal roles.

2. **Subservience to Men**: The text underscores the importance of a woman being correct in manner and upright in character solely to serve her husband. This reflects a societal structure where women were expected to be subordinate to men, a trend that intensified with the development of more complex social hierarchies.

3. **Limited Autonomy**: The passage suggests that women should not engage in gossip or silly laughter and should focus on domestic duties. This indicates a lack of autonomy for women, as their activities and social interactions were heavily regulated and expected to be within the confines of their domestic responsibilities.

4. **Ancestral Worship and Purity**: The text also highlights the importance of women continuing ancestral worship by performing domestic duties related to food and drink offerings. This duty is presented as a moral obligation, further constraining women to their prescribed roles and responsibilities.

In summary, women's lives in the period 600 BCE to 600 CE were generally more restricted than before the advent of sedentary societies because their roles became more confined to the private sphere, they were expected to be subservient to men, and their autonomy was significantly limited. The passage from Ban Zhao's work provides a snapshot of these societal expectations during a time when the structure of societies was becoming more complex and hierarchical.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
The passage below is the Chinese emperor's response to English King George III's diplomatic envoys, who were seeking expanded trading privileges (1793).
Strange and costly objects do not interest me. If I have commanded that the tribute offerings sent by you, O King, are to be accepted, this was solely in consideration for the spirit which prompted you to dispatch them from afar. . . . As your Ambassador can see for himself, we possess all things. I set no value on objects strange or ingenious, and have no use for your country's manufactures. It behooves you, O King, to display even greater devotion and loyalty in future, so that, by perpetual submission to our Throne, you may secure peace and prosperity.
According to the passage, what was the Chinese reaction to the British goods? (A) Interpreting them as an act of submission (B) Offense at a perceived bribe
pred:
The Chinese emperor's response indicates that he viewed the British goods as a form of tribute rather than as items of trade or a bribe. The emperor's words suggest that he accepted the goods primarily as a gesture of loyalty and devotion from King George III, emphasizing that the acceptance was more about the spirit of submission and perpetual loyalty to the Chinese throne than about any practical need or interest in the goods themselves. Therefore, the correct answer to the question is:

(A) Interpreting them as an act of submission

question:
This question refers to the following information.
"To slacken the tempo would mean falling behind. And those who fall behind get beaten. But we do not want to be beaten. No, we refuse to be beaten! One feature of the history of old Russia was the continual beatings she suffered because of her backwardness. She was beaten by the Mongol khans. She was beaten by the Turkish beys. She was beaten by the Swedish feudal lords. She was beaten by the Polish and Lithuanian gentry. She was beaten by the British and French capitalists. She was beaten by the Japanese barons. All beat her––because of her backwardness, because of her military backwardness, cultural backwardness, political backwardness, industrial backwardness, agricultural backwardness. They beat her because it was profitable and could be done with impunity. You remember the words of the pre-revolutionary poet: "You are poor and abundant, mighty and impotent, Mother Russia." Those gentlemen were quite familiar with the verses of the old poet. They beat her, saying: "You are abundant," so one can enrich oneself at your expense. They beat her, saying: "You are poor and impotent," so you can be beaten and plundered with impunity. Such is the law of the exploiters––to beat the backward and the weak. It is the jungle law of capitalism. You are backward, you are weak––therefore you are wrong; hence you can be beaten and enslaved. You are mighty––therefore you are right; hence we must be wary of you.
That is why we must no longer lag behind."
Joseph Stalin, speech delivered at the first All-Union Conference of Leading Personnel of Socialist Industry, February 4, 1931
The speech as a whole is best understood in the context of which of the following historical developments? (A) Stalin's implementation of five-year plans for the Soviet economy (B) Stalin's drive to motivate Soviet industry for the Winter War with Finland
pred:
The speech by Joseph Stalin, delivered at the first All-Union Conference of Leading Personnel of Socialist Industry on February 4, 1931, is best understood in the context of (B) Stalin's drive to motivate Soviet industry for the Winter War with Finland.

This speech was given during a period when the Soviet Union was engaged in military conflict with Finland, known as the Winter War. Stalin was rallying industrial leaders and workers to accelerate industrial production and military output to support the Soviet Union's efforts in this conflict. The speech emphasizes the need for the Soviet Union to catch up with and surpass its adversaries, both in terms of industrial and military capabilities, to avoid being "beaten" or exploited by other nations, as had been the case historically.

Stalin's words reflect his broader policy of rapid industrialization and militarization, which was a key part of his strategy to modernize the Soviet Union and make it a formidable power capable of defending itself against external threats. This policy was implemented through the five-year plans, which indeed were a significant part of Soviet economic strategy, but the specific reference in the question to the Winter War situates this speech more directly within the context of the immediate military and industrial mobilization efforts during that conflict.

pred:

(A) The British crown offered incentives to those who would establish homesteads in the unsettled lands of South Africa.

It mentions that the citizen had recently insured his "little homestead in the city" for £2,000 and also refers to a farm of 50 acres near the town that would likely suffer damage from the actions of the Zulu natives. - There is no mention in the provided text of a diamond rush or the discovery of diamonds on Zulu lands in 1867.

Thus, the most accurate reason based on the letter's content is (A).

question:
This question refers to the following information.
"The struggle against neo-colonialism is not aimed at excluding the capital of the developed world from operating in less developed countries. It is aimed at preventing the financial power of the developed countries being used in such a way as to impoverish the less developed.
Non-alignment, as practiced by Ghana and many other countries, is based on co-operation with all States whether they be capitalist, socialist or have a mixed economy. Such a policy, therefore, involves foreign investment from capitalist countries, but it must be invested in accordance with a national plan drawn up by the government of the non-aligned State with its own interests in mind. The issue is not what return the foreign investor receives on his investments…The question is one of power. A State in the grip of neo-colonialism is not master of its own destiny."
Kwame Nkrumah, Neo-Colonialism, 1965
Which of the following most inspired the national plan advanced by Nkrumah in the second paragraph? (A) Socialism (B) Classical liberalism
pred:
The answer to the question is inspired by Kwame Nkrumah's statement on the nature of non-alignment and the principles underlying his approach to foreign investment and national planning. Nkrumah emphasizes that the goal is not to exclude developed countries' capital from less developed countries but to ensure that this capital does not lead to the impoverishment of these countries and that the control and benefits of development remain in the hands of the local government.

From the provided text, the inspiration for Nkrumah's national plan is most closely aligned with the principle of non-alignment, which involves cooperation with all states regardless of their economic system (capitalist, socialist, or mixed). This implies a focus on self-determination and sovereignty over the economic policies and development paths of the country. The statement also suggests that the primary concern is not the financial returns for foreign investors but rather the control and benefits of development remaining within the country itself.

Given the options:

(A) Socialism - While socialism might align with the idea of controlling economic benefits within the country, Nkrumah's statement does not explicitly mention socialism as the inspiration for his national plan. It focuses more on the principle of non-alignment and self-determination.

(B) Classical liberalism - Classical liberalism typically emphasizes individual freedom, free markets, and limited government intervention. While these principles might support the idea of foreign investment and free trade, they do not directly address the issue of ensuring that the benefits of development remain within the country or the control of the government over its economic destiny, which are central to Nkrumah's argument.

Based on Nkrumah's words, the most accurate inspiration for his national plan is the principle of non-alignment, which prioritizes cooperation with all states while maintaining control over the country's economic development and destiny. This principle is not directly represented by classical liberalism but is more closely aligned with a form of economic nationalism and self-reliance that ensures the benefits of development are retained within the country. Therefore, the answer is not directly provided by the options given, but if one must choose from them, socialism might be the closest match due to its emphasis on control over economic systems and benefits within the country, although this interpretation stretches beyond the explicit mention in Nkrumah's statement.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
Source 1:
"It is impossible to demand that an impossible position should be cleared up by peaceful revision and at the same time constantly reject peaceful revision. It is also impossible to say that he who undertakes to carry out these revisions for himself transgresses a law, since the Versailles "Diktat" is not law to us. A signature was forced out of us with pistols at our head and with the threat of hunger for millions of people. And then this document, with our signature, obtained by force, was proclaimed as a solemn law."
Adolf Hitler, speech to the Reichstag, September 1, 1939
Source 2:
"We shall not flag or fail. We shall go on to the end. We shall fight in France, we shall fight on the seas and the oceans, we shall fight with growing confidence and growing strength in the air, we shall defend our island, whatever the cost may be. We shall fight on the beaches, we shall fight on the landing grounds, we shall fight in the fields and in the streets, we shall fight in the hills; we shall never surrender."
Winston Churchill, speech before Parliament, June 4, 1940
Winston Churchill's speech in Source 2 is best understood in the context of which of the following? (A) British fears about a possible invasion attempt by Nazi Germany (B) British appeasement of the Axis powers
pred: Winston Churchill's speech in Source 2 is best understood in the context of British fears about a possible invasion attempt by Nazi Germany. This is because Churchill's speech, delivered on June 4, 1940, was made during the early stages of World War II, when Nazi Germany had already invaded and occupied several European countries. Churchill's words were a rallying cry to the British people, emphasizing their determination to resist the German invasion and defend their homeland at all costs. The speech reflects the urgency and gravity of the situation, with Churchill promising an unyielding defense against the Axis powers, particularly Nazi Germany. This context aligns with option (A) and captures the essence of Churchill's call to arms and the dire circumstances faced by Britain at the time.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
"The spontaneous forces of capitalism have been steadily growing in the countryside in recent years, with new rich peasants springing up everywhere and many well-to-do middle peasants striving to become rich peasants. On the other hand, many poor peasants are still living in poverty for lack of sufficient means of production, with some in debt and others selling or renting out their land. If this tendency goes unchecked, the polarization in the countryside will inevitably be aggravated day by day. Those peasants who lose their land and those who remain in poverty will complain that we are doing nothing to save them from ruin or to help them overcome their difficulties. Nor will the well-to-do middle peasants who are heading in the capitalist direction be pleased with us, for we shall never be able to satisfy their demands unless we intend to take the capitalist road. Can the worker-peasant alliance continue to stand in these circumstances? Obviously not! There is no solution to this problem except on a new basis. And that means to bring about, step by step, the socialist transformation of the whole of agriculture simultaneously with the gradual realization of socialist industrialization and the socialist transformation of handicrafts and capitalist industry and commerce; in other words, it means to carry out co-operation and eliminate the rich-peasant economy and the individual economy in the countryside so that all the rural people will become increasingly well off together. We maintain that this is the only way to consolidate the worker-peasant alliance."
Mao Zedong, On the Question of Agricultural Co-operation, 1955
Which of the following later developments would most undermine the hopes expressed by Mao in the second-to-last line of the passage? (A) The cooperatives of peasants on the farmland and an emphasis on countryside steel production brought famine and poverty to the Chinese peasantry. (B) Opposition voices in the Communist Party led by men such as Deng Xiaopeng were rooted out and silenced during the Cultural Revolution.
pred:
The answer to the question, which later development would most undermine the hopes expressed by Mao in the second-to-last line of the passage, is (A) The cooperatives of peasants on the farmland and an emphasis on countryside steel production brought famine and poverty to the Chinese peasantry.

Explanation:
Mao Zedong's hope was for a collective, cooperative approach to agriculture that would lead to the well-being of all rural people together, eliminating the rich-peasant economy and individual economic activities in the countryside. However, the implementation of the Great Leap Forward, which included the establishment of peasant cooperatives and the emphasis on steel production in rural areas, led to disastrous consequences. The focus on steel production diverted resources and labor away from food production, resulting in widespread famine and poverty. The Great Leap Forward and its associated policies led to the deaths of millions due to starvation and related diseases.

This development directly contradicted Mao's vision of all rural people becoming increasingly well off together. Instead, it resulted in widespread suffering and undermined the worker-peasant alliance Mao sought to strengthen. The other options (B) and (C) do not directly contradict Mao's vision in the same way:

(B) Opposition voices within the Communist Party being silenced during the Cultural Revolution did not undermine Mao's agricultural vision per se; it was more about political control and suppression of dissent. While it had long-term negative effects on the Party and the country, it did not directly affect the agricultural policies or their outcomes.

(C) The gradual shift towards market-oriented reforms under Deng Xiaoping and the eventual dismantling of communes and the introduction of the Household Responsibility System in the late 1970s did not occur until after Mao's death and the end of the Cultural Revolution. While these reforms moved away from Mao's vision of collective agriculture, they were a response to the failures of the Great Leap Forward and were intended to improve agricultural productivity and living standards. Thus, they can be seen as an attempt to correct the mistakes made during Mao's era rather than directly undermining his hopes as expressed in the passage.

In summary, the development that most undermines Mao's hopes expressed in the passage is the Great Leap Forward and its associated policies, which led to famine and poverty among the peasantry, directly contradicting Mao's vision of all rural people becoming increasingly well off together.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
By what principle of reason then, should these foreigners send in return a poisonous drug? Without meaning to say that the foreigners harbor such destructive intentions in their hearts, we yet positively assert that from their inordinate thirst after gain, they are perfectly careless about the injuries they inflict upon us! And such being the case, we should like to ask what has become of that conscience which heaven has implanted in the breasts of all men? We have heard that in your own country opium is prohibited with the utmost strictness and severity. This is a strong proof that you know full well how hurtful it is to mankind. Since you do not permit it to injure your own country, you ought not to have this injurious drug transferred to another country, and above all others, how much less to the Inner Land! Of the products which China exports to your foreign countries, there is not one which is not beneficial to mankind in some shape or other.
Lin Zexu, Chinese trade commissioner, letter to Queen Victoria, 1839

1. **Foreigners sending a "poisonous drug"**: Lin Zexu refers to opium as a "poisonous drug," which directly points to the British trade of opium in China.

2. **Injuries inflicted by the foreigners**: The complaint about the "injuries" inflicted by the foreigners through the opium trade is explicit.

3. **Prohibition of opium in Britain**: Lin Zexu notes that opium is strictly prohibited in Britain, indicating that the British themselves recognize the harm that opium can cause to mankind.

4. **Request for action**: Lin Zexu's letter is a request for Queen Victoria to take action against the British opium trade in China, as he believes it is unethical and harmful.

Given these points, the most likely answer to the question "Which of the following most likely prompted the complaint voiced in the passage?" is:

**A) British sale of opium in China**

This option directly aligns with the content of Lin Zexu's complaint and the context provided in the passage. The other options do not match the details presented in the text.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
Gunpowder Weaponry: Europe vs. China
In Western Europe during the 1200s through the 1400s, early cannons, as heavy and as slow to fire as they were, proved useful enough in the protracted sieges that dominated warfare during this period that governments found it sufficiently worthwhile to pay for them and for the experimentation that eventually produced gunpowder weapons that were both more powerful and easier to move. By contrast, China, especially after the mid-1300s, was threatened mainly by highly mobile steppe nomads, against whom early gunpowder weapons, with their unwieldiness, proved of little utility. It therefore devoted its efforts to the improvement of horse archer units who could effectively combat the country's deadliest foe.
According to this passage, why did the Chinese, despite inventing gunpowder, fail to lead in the innovation of gunpowder weaponry? (A) They logically decided to develop weapons better suited to their immediate military needs. (B) They could not afford the initial expense of converting to a new military technology.
pred:
The answer to the question is (A) They logically decided to develop weapons better suited to their immediate military needs.

Explanation: The passage states that China, especially after the mid-1300s, was threatened mainly by highly mobile steppe nomads. These nomads were effective in hit-and-run tactics and were difficult to engage in conventional warfare. Early gunpowder weapons, such as cannons, were described as being "unwieldy" and "slow to fire," which would have been ineffective against these fast-moving adversaries. As a result, the Chinese focused their efforts on improving their horse archer units, which were better suited to counter the mobility of the steppe nomads. This strategic decision prioritized the development of weapons and tactics that directly addressed their most pressing military challenges, rather than investing in gunpowder weaponry that was not immediately practical for their needs.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
The condition of foreign states is not what it once was; they have invented the steamship, and introduced radical changes in the art of navigation. They have also built up their armies to a state of great efficiency and are possessed of war implements of great power and precision, in short have license to be formidable powers. If, therefore, we persistently cling to our antiquated systems, heaven only knows what a mighty calamity may befall our Empire.
—Adapted from a letter written by Lord Ii to Lord Tokugawa, 1847
How did Japan respond to the concerns raised by Lord Ii during this era? (A) The country sent emissaries to study western democracies and industry. (B) The country turned inward and closed its ports to all foreigners.
pred:
The correct answer to the question, based on the provided information, is:

(B) The country turned inward and closed its ports to all foreigners.

Explanation: The passage from Lord Ii's letter to Lord Tokugawa in 1847 highlights the concerns regarding the advancements and military capabilities of foreign states, particularly in steamships, navigation, and weaponry. It suggests that Japan was facing the threat of becoming obsolete in the face of rapidly progressing Western technology and military might. In response to these concerns, Japan chose to "turn inward" and adopt a policy of Sakoku, which effectively closed the country to most foreign influences and trade. This policy included the closure of ports and the prohibition of foreign travel, with the exception of a limited number of Dutch traders who were allowed to operate in the isolated trading post of Dejima in Nagasaki. This inward turn was a defensive measure to protect Japan's traditional ways of life and to avoid the perceived threats associated with Western influence and imperialism. This policy lasted until the mid-19th century when Commodore Perry's Black Ships forced Japan to open up again to foreign trade and interaction.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
At the peak of their power, the domains of the Mongol khans, or rulers, made up a vast realm in which once-hostile peoples lived together in peace and virtually all religions were tolerated. . . . The law code first promulgated by Chinggis Khan ordered human interaction. The result was an important new stage in international contact. From eastern Europe to southern China, merchants and travelers could move across the well-policed Mongol domains without fear for their lives or property. The great swath of Mongol territory that covered or connected most of Europe, Asia, and the Middle East served as a bridge between the civilizations of the Eastern Hemisphere. The caravans and embassies that crossed the Mongol lands transmitted new food, inventions, and ideas from one civilized pool to others and from civilized pools to the nomadic peoples who served as intermediaries. Secure trade routes made for prosperous merchants and wealthy, cosmopolitan cities. They also facilitated the spread of foods [and] inventions . . . a major force for economic and social development and the enhancement of civilized life.
—Robert Guisepi, 1992
Which of the following was a long-term consequence of the Mongol conquest of Russia in the 1200s? (A) Russia developed a centralized bureaucracy. (B) Russia was excluded from Western European developments

The long-term consequence of the Mongol conquest of Russia in the 1200s that aligns with the provided information is:

(A) Russia developed a centralized bureaucracy.

Explanation: The Mongol rule over Russia led to the establishment of a centralized administration. The Mongols introduced a system of governance that required a structured bureaucracy to manage the diverse peoples and territories under their control. This system facilitated the integration of various ethnic groups and regions into a single political entity, which laid the groundwork for a more centralized form of governance in Russia. Over time, this Mongol-imposed administrative structure evolved and became a significant aspect of Russian state organization, contributing to the development of a more centralized bureaucracy in later Russian history.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
"And then Shapur, King of Kings, passed away. Then his son Hormizd, King of Kings, rose over the empire. And Hormizd, King of Kings, conferred on me cap and belt and created for me a higher rank and dignity, and at court and in kingdom after kingdom, place after place, throughout the whole empire he gave me more authority and power in matters of the divine services, and created for me the title "Kerdir, Ahura Mazda's [Chief Priest]" after the name of Ahura Mazda, the Deity. And thereupon in kingdom after kingdom, place after place, many divine services were performed in magnificence, and many Warham fires were established, and many magi became happy and prosperous, and many fires and magi were imperially installed…
And then Hormizd, King of Kings, passed away. Then Bahram, King of Kings, son of Shapur, King of Kings, and brother of Hormizd, King of Kings, rose over the empire. And Bahram, King of Kings, also held me in high honor and dignity and at court and in kingdom after kingdom, place after place, gave me authority and power for divine services of every sort. And thereupon in kingdom after kingdom, place after place, many divine services were performed in magnificence and many Warharan fires were established, and many magi became happy and prosperous, and many fires and magi were imperially installed…
And in kingdom after kingdom and place after place throughout the whole empire the services of Ahura Mazda and the gods became preeminent, and great dignity came to the Mazdayanian religion and the magi in the empire, and the gods and water and fire and small cattle in the empire attained great satisfaction, while Ahriman [the evil counterpart to Ahura Mazda] and the demons were punished and rebuked, and the teachings of Ahriman and the demons departed from the empire and were abandoned. And Jews, Buddhists, Hindus, Nasoreans [Orthodox Christians], Christians, Maktak [Baptists], and Manichaeans in the empire were smitten, and destruction of idols and scattering of the stores of the demons and god-seats and nests was abandoned."
Excerpt from the inscription of Kerdir at Naqsh-e-Rustam, Persia, late third century C.E.
Which of the following best describes Persia's relationship with Arabia in the period 600–1450 C.E.? (A) Persia supported Arabian client states throughout the period. (B) Persia was brought into the Arabian orbit over the course of the period.
pred:
The passage describes the actions and policies of the Sassanid Persian kings Shapur, Hormizd, and Bahram towards the Zoroastrian religion and its priests, the magi. It mentions the establishment of Warham fires (Zoroastrian temples) and the promotion of the Mazdayanian religion, which indicates that during these periods, the Sassanid kings actively supported and promoted Zoroastrianism as the state religion.

The excerpt also mentions interactions with various religious groups, including Jews, Buddhists, Hindus, Nasoreans (Orthodox Christians), Christians, Maktaks (Baptists), and Manichaeans, indicating a complex relationship with other religious communities. It suggests that these groups were sometimes "smitten" or faced some form of persecution, while the teachings of Ahriman (the evil deity in Zoroastrianism) and the demons were rebuked.

Given this context, the relationship between Persia (Sassanid Empire) and Arabia from 600 to 1450 C.E. cannot be accurately described as either (A) Persia supporting Arabian client states throughout the period or (B) Persia being brought into the Arabian orbit over the course of the period based solely on the provided excerpt.

The period from 600 to 1450 C.E. is significant as it encompasses the rise and fall of the Sassanid Empire, the Islamic conquests, and the establishment of various Islamic caliphates. The Sassanid Empire was in decline by the 7th century and eventually fell to the Arab Islamic conquests. After the Islamic conquest, Persia (Iran) became part of the Islamic world and was governed by various Islamic caliphates and dynasties.

The relationship between Persia and Arabia during this time was complex and evolved over centuries:

1. **Early Islamic Period (600s-750s):** Persia was conquered by Arab Muslims, and the region became part of the expanding Islamic Caliphate. The Arab rulers imposed Islam on the population, and Arabic became the dominant language.

2. **Post-Conquest Period (750s-1450):** Persia (Iran) gradually developed its own Islamic culture and identity under the rule of various Islamic dynasties, such as the Abbasid, Seljuk, and Mongol Empires. While Persia was part of the broader Islamic world, it also maintained its own distinct cultural and political identity.

3. **Religious Dynamics:** The relationship between Persia and Arabia in terms of religion was one of conversion and cultural assimilation. The majority of Persians converted to Islam, but Zoroastrianism, Christianity, and other religions continued to exist in various forms.

4. **Trade and Cultural Exchange:** Despite political changes, trade and cultural exchange between Persia and Arabia continued throughout this period. The Silk Road and other trade routes facilitated the exchange of goods, ideas, and religious influences.

Based on this historical context, neither option (A) nor (B) fully encapsulates the nuanced relationship between Persia and Arabia from 600 to 1450 C.E. Persia was not consistently a client state of Arabian powers throughout this period, nor was it entirely brought into the Arabian orbit. Instead, Persia evolved within the Islamic world, maintaining its own identity while also participating in the broader Islamic cultural and political landscape. The relationship was characterized by periods of integration and assimilation, as well as periods of distinct cultural and political autonomy.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
New York! I say New York, let black blood flow into your blood.
Let it wash the rust from your steel joints, like an oil of life
Let it give your bridges the curve of hips and supple vines…
See your rivers stirring with musk alligators
And sea cows with mirage eyes…
Just open your eyes to the April rainbow
And your eyes, especially your ears, to God
Who in one burst of saxophone laughter
Created heaven and earth in six days,
And on the seventh slept a deep Negro sleep.
Senegalese poet Léopold Sédar Senghor, "To New York," 1956
Which of the following best explains the phenomenon of an African poet writing so lyrically about New York? (A) Stronger transatlantic influences linking art in Afro-Eurasia with that in the Americas (B) Outmigration from Africa due to political violence
pred:
The correct answer to the question, which is not provided among the options given, would be:

(A) Stronger transatlantic influences linking art in Afro-Eurasia with that in the Americas

Explanation:
Léopold Sédar Senghor, a Senegalese poet, writing lyrically about New York in 1956 reflects the broader phenomenon of cultural exchange and artistic influence across the Atlantic Ocean. This period, often referred to as the "Age of Transatlantic Travel," saw significant movement of people, ideas, and cultural expressions between Africa, Europe, and the Americas. Artists and intellectuals from Africa, including Senghor, were influenced by and contributed to the cultural dialogues happening in the United States and other parts of the Americas. This influence is evident in Senghor's use of imagery and themes that resonate with both African and American cultural contexts, such as the natural beauty and urban vibrancy of New York. His poem celebrates the city's dynamism and contrasts it with the serene, creative force of African heritage, illustrating a fusion of cultures that transcends geographical boundaries. This phenomenon is supported by historical evidence of cultural exchanges, including the Harlem Renaissance, which was a cultural movement in the 1920s that celebrated African American art, music, literature, and intellectualism, attracting artists from around the world, including African writers and thinkers.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
"From the confines of Jerusalem and the city of Constantinople a horrible tale has gone forth and very frequently has been brought to our ears, namely, that a race from the kingdom of the Persians, an accursed race, a race utterly alienated from God, a generation forsooth which has not directed its heart and has not entrusted its spirit to God, has invaded the lands of those Christians and has depopulated them by the sword, pillage and fire; it has led away a part of the captives into its own country, and a part it has destroyed by cruel tortures; it has either entirely destroyed the churches of God or appropriated them for the rites of its own religion….The kingdom of the Greeks is now dismembered by them and deprived of territory so vast in extent that it cannot be traversed in a march of two months. On whom therefore is the labor of avenging these wrongs and of recovering this territory incumbent, if not upon you? You, upon whom above other nations God has conferred remarkable glory in arms, great courage, bodily activity, and strength to humble the hairy scalp of those who resist you.
Let the deeds of your ancestors move you and incite your minds to manly achievements; the glory and greatness of king Charles the Great, and of his son Louis, and of your other kings, who have destroyed the kingdoms of the pagans, and extended in these lands the territory of the holy church. Let the holy sepulchre of the Lord our Savior, which is possessed by unclean nations, especially incite you, and the holy places which are now treated with ignominy and irreverently polluted with their filthiness. Oh, most valiant soldiers and descendants of invincible ancestors, be not degenerate, but recall the valor of your progenitors.
Jerusalem is the navel of the world; the land is fruitful above others, like another paradise of delights. This the Redeemer of the human race has made illustrious by His advent, has beautified by residence, has consecrated by suffering, has redeemed by death, has glorified by burial. This royal city, therefore, situated at the center of the world, is now held captive by His enemies, and is in subjection to those who do not know God, to the worship of the heathens. She seeks therefore and desires to be liberated and does not cease to implore you to come to her aid. From you especially she asks succor, because, as we have already said, God has conferred upon you above all nations great glory in arms. Accordingly undertake this journey for the remission of your sins, with the assurance of the imperishable glory of the kingdom of heaven."
Pope Urban II, Speech at the Council of Clermont as recorded by Robert the Monk, 1095 C.E.
The speech above is best understood in context of which of the following? (A) The Crusades (B) The Mongol invasions of the Middle East
pred:
The speech above is best understood in the context of the Crusades (A). Pope Urban II's address at the Council of Clermont in 1095 C.E. was a pivotal moment in history, marking the beginning of the Crusades. In his speech, he called upon Christian knights in Europe to take up arms, travel to the Holy Land, and reclaim Jerusalem and other sacred sites from Muslim control. The speech emphasizes the religious, moral, and spiritual motivations for the knights to embark on this military campaign, framing it as a holy war to reclaim Christian lands, redeem their sins through battle, and secure access to the holy sites for Christians.

The Crusades were a series of military campaigns initiated by the Latin Church in the medieval period, primarily aimed at reclaiming Jerusalem and the Holy Land from Muslim rule. They spanned several centuries, from the 11th to the 13th century, and involved various groups of European knights, nobles, and commoners who set out for the Holy Land to participate in battles, establish Christian kingdoms, and, in some cases, convert Muslims to Christianity.

The Mongol invasions of the Middle East (B) occurred later and were led by Genghis Khan and his successors. While these invasions had a significant impact on the region, they were not the immediate cause or the primary focus of Pope Urban II's call to arms. The Mongol invasions primarily targeted the Abbasid Caliphate, the Seljuk Turks, and other Muslim states in the Middle East, and while they did result in the destruction of some Muslim powers and changes in the political landscape of the region, they did not directly threaten Christian control over the Holy Land or the holy sites in Jerusalem in the same way that the Seljuk Turks and other Muslim rulers did at the time of Urban II's speech.

Thus, the speech by Pope Urban II is most directly related to the context of the Crusades, as it was a call to action against the specific threats to Christian control of the Holy Land and the need to reclaim these lands for Christianity.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
"When the Portuguese go from Macao in China to Japan, they carry much white silk, gold, musk, and porcelain: and they bring from Japan nothing but silver. They have a great carrack which goes there every year and she brings from there every year about six hundred coins: and all this silver of Japan, and two hundred thousand coins more in silver which they bring yearly out of India, they employ to their great advantage in China: and they bring from there gold, musk, silk, copper, porcelains, and many other things very costly and gilded.
When the Portuguese come to Canton in China to traffic, they must remain there but certain days: and when they come in at the gate of the city, they must enter their names in a book, and when they go out at night they must put out their names. They may not lie in the town all night, but must lie in their boats outside of the town. And, their time expired, if any man remains there, he is imprisoned."
Ralph Fitch, an account of his travels to the Far East, 1599 C.E.
The description in the second paragraph of the procedures that Portuguese and other foreigners followed when trading in China supports which of the following inferences about trade policy in the later Ming Dynasty? (A) The Ming Dynasty sought to regulate trade strictly to limit contact with foreigners and ease collection of taxes. (B) The Ming Dynasty only allowed Portugal to trade with China through Canton, permitting only one boat a year.
pred:
The description provided by Ralph Fitch in 1599 C.E. outlines several regulations and restrictions placed on the Portuguese traders when they engaged in trade at Canton, which was one of the primary ports open to foreign trade during the later Ming Dynasty in China. Here are the key points that support the inference about trade policy in the later Ming Dynasty:

1. **Regulation of Entry and Exit**: The Portuguese traders were required to register their names upon entering Canton and were monitored by having to put out their names when leaving at night. This indicates a strict regulation of foreign traders' movements and activities within the city.

2. **Time Limitation**: Foreign traders were only allowed to stay in Canton for a limited period, suggesting that the Ming Dynasty sought to control the duration of foreign presence in the country.

3. **Restrictions on Accommodation**: Foreigners were not allowed to stay in the town overnight but had to reside in their boats outside the city. This restriction further illustrates the control over foreign presence and interaction with the local population and economy.

4. **Monopoly on Trade**: The mention of only one carrack (ship) per year from Portugal indicates a highly regulated and limited trade policy. This suggests that the Ming Dynasty imposed strict controls on the volume and frequency of foreign trade, likely to minimize the impact of foreign influence and control over Chinese trade.

Based on these points, the inference (A) is supported: "The Ming Dynasty sought to regulate trade strictly to limit contact with foreigners and ease collection of taxes." This inference aligns with the described policies aimed at controlling and limiting foreign trade, minimizing foreign presence, and maintaining control over the trade process and its economic implications.

Option (B) is not supported by the description provided, as it incorrectly suggests that only Portugal was allowed to trade with China through Canton, permitting only one boat a year. While the text mentions Portugal's specific trade scenario, it does not state that this was the only arrangement for all foreign trade with China. Other foreign entities might have had different or more extensive trading privileges, depending on the evolving dynamics of the Ming Dynasty's trade policies over time.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
Is it not unity alone that can weld us into an effective force, capable of creating our own progress and making our valuable contribution to world peace? Which independent African state will claim that its financial structure and banking institutions are fully harnessed to its national development? Which will claim that its material resources and human energies are available for its own national aspirations? We are fast learning that political independence is not enough to rid us of the consequences of colonial rule. We have been too busy nursing our separate states to understand fully the basic need for union, rooted in common purpose, common planning and common endeavour.
Ghana's president, Kwame Nkrumah, addressing the Organization of African Unity, 1963
The speaker in the passage above is espousing which of the following causes? (A) Pan-Africanism (B) Nationalism
pred:
The speaker in the passage is espousing the cause of Pan-Africanism. 

Explanation:
The passage discusses the idea that unity among African states is essential for creating progress and contributing to world peace. It emphasizes that political independence alone is insufficient to overcome the consequences of colonial rule and that there is a need for a deeper union based on common purposes, planning, and endeavors. The speaker, Kwame Nkrumah, was a prominent advocate for Pan-Africanism, a philosophy that promotes unity and solidarity among African nations to achieve common goals, including economic development, social progress, and political independence.

Pan-Africanism contrasts with nationalism, which focuses on the interests and aspirations of individual nations without necessarily emphasizing unity or cooperation among them. The passage explicitly states that nursing separate states has hindered the understanding of the need for union, indicating a preference for a collective approach over individualistic nationalism.

Therefore, the correct answer to the question is (A) Pan-Africanism.

question:

By what principle of reason then, should these foreigners send in return a poisonous drug? Without meaning to say that the foreigners harbor such destructive intentions in their hearts, we yet positively assert that from their inordinate thirst after gain, they are perfectly careless about the injuries they inflict upon us! And such being the case, we should like to ask what has become of that conscience which heaven has implanted in the breasts of all men? We have heard that in your own country opium is prohibited with the utmost strictness and severity. This is a strong proof that you know full well how hurtful it is to mankind. Since you do not permit it to injure your own country, you ought not to have this injurious drug transferred to another country, and above all others, how much less to the Inner Land! Of the products which China exports to your foreign countries, there is not one which is not beneficial to mankind in some shape or other.
Lin Zexu, Chinese trade commissioner, letter to Queen Victoria, 1839
On which of the following arguments does the author of the passage principally base his appeal? (A) It is hypocritical to sell one country a substance banned as harmful in one's own. (B) Britain is unwise to risk the wrath of a militarily more powerful state.
pred: The author of the passage principally bases his appeal on argument (A): "It is hypocritical to sell one country a substance banned as harmful in one's own." This argument is central to Lin Zexu's letter to Queen Victoria. He accuses the foreigners (presumably the British) of being driven by greed and being indifferent to the harm their actions cause to China, citing the prohibition of opium in Britain as evidence of their awareness of opium's harmful effects. He argues that if opium is considered so harmful in Britain that it is banned, then it is hypocritical for the British to export it to China, where it causes significant harm. This appeal to hypocrisy is a key part of his argument for why Britain should not continue the opium trade with China.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
Yi Yin sacrificed to the former king, and presented the heir-king reverently before the shrine of his grandfather. . . . Yi Yin then clearly described the virtue of the Meritorious Ancestor for the instruction of the young king.
"Oh! of old the former kings of Xia cultivated earnestly their virtue, and then there were no calamities from Heaven. The spirits of the hills and rivers were all in tranquility; and the birds and beasts enjoyed their existence according to their nature. But their descendant did not follow their example, and Heaven sent down calamities, using our ruler, who possessed of its favor. The attack on Xia may be traced to the orgies in Ming Tiao. . . . Our king of Shang brilliantly displayed his sagely prowess; for oppression he substituted his generous gentleness. Now your Majesty is entering on the inheritance of his virtue; all depends on how you commence your reign.
"Oh! the former king began with careful attention to the bonds that hold men together. . . . Revere these warnings in your person. . . . The ways of Heaven are not invariable: on the good-doer it sends down all blessings, and on the evil-doer it sends down all miseries. If you not be virtuous, be it in large things or in small, it will bring the ruin of your ancestral temple."
—Excerpted and adapted from the Shu Jing, 6th century BCE, China
What does the phrase below tell us about the ruler? (A) He had the Mandate of Heaven. (B) He was killed as a result of natural disasters.
pred:
The phrase in question is an excerpt from the "Shu Jing" (Classic of History), which dates back to the 6th century BCE in China. It describes the actions and advice given to a young king by Yi Yin, a revered minister and advisor.

The phrase in question is:

"Oh! the former king began with careful attention to the bonds that hold men together. . . . Revere these warnings in your person. . . . The ways of Heaven are not invariable: on the good-doer it sends down all blessings, and on the evil-doer it sends down all miseries. If you not be virtuous, be it in large things or in small, it will bring the ruin of your ancestral temple."

From this passage, we can infer the following about the ruler:

(A) He had the Mandate of Heaven: The concept of the Mandate of Heaven (Tian Ming) in Chinese philosophy suggests that the ruler's right to govern is granted by heaven and can be lost if the ruler is immoral or fails to govern well. The passage emphasizes the importance of virtue and warns that failing to be virtuous can lead to the ruin of the ancestral temple, which is a metaphor for the downfall of the ruler and the dynasty. This aligns with the idea of the Mandate of Heaven, as it suggests that the ruler's actions and virtue are directly linked to the continued prosperity of the state and the legitimacy of their rule.

(B) He was killed as a result of natural disasters: The passage does not explicitly state that the ruler was killed as a result of natural disasters. Instead, it focuses on the consequences of the ruler's virtue (or lack thereof) on the dynasty's prosperity and the ruler's legitimacy. While it does mention "calamities from Heaven" as a consequence of the former kings' actions, it does not directly attribute the downfall of the ruler to natural disasters. The passage is more concerned with the moral and ethical conduct of the ruler and its impact on the dynasty's fate.

Therefore, the correct answer based on the provided information is:

(A) He had the Mandate of Heaven.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
"The Romanists have, with great adroitness, drawn three walls round themselves, with which they have hitherto protected themselves, so that no one could reform them, whereby all Christendom has fallen terribly.
Firstly, if pressed by the temporal power, they have affirmed and maintained that the temporal power has no jurisdiction over them, but, on the contrary, that the spiritual power is above the temporal.
Secondly, if it were proposed to admonish them with the Scriptures, they objected that no one may interpret the Scriptures but the Pope.
Thirdly, if they are threatened with a council, they pretend that no one may call a council but the Pope…
…The second wall is even more tottering and weak: that they alone pretend to be considered masters of the Scriptures; although they learn nothing of them all their life. They assume authority, and juggle before us with impudent words, saying that the Pope cannot err in matters of faith, whether he be evil or good, albeit they cannot prove it by a single letter. That is why the canon law contains so many heretical and unchristian, nay unnatural, laws; but of these we need not speak now. For whereas they imagine the Holy Ghost never leaves them, however unlearned and wicked they may be, they grow bold enough to decree whatever they like. But were this true, where were the need and use of the Holy Scriptures? Let us burn them, and content ourselves with the unlearned gentlemen at Rome, in whom the Holy Ghost dwells, who, however, can dwell in pious souls only. If I had not read it, I could never have believed that the devil should have put forth such follies at Rome and find a following."
Martin Luther, Address to the Nobility of the German Nation, 1520
How is the "temporal power" mentioned in the passage best understood contextually? (A) A state or secular authority (B) A clerical or ecclesiastical authority
pred: The "temporal power" mentioned in the passage by Martin Luther is best understood as (A) a state or secular authority. In the context provided, Luther is discussing how the Roman Catholic Church has positioned itself against external secular authorities, asserting that the spiritual power (the Church) is above the temporal power (the state). This is evident in the first point made by Luther, where he states that the Romanists (a term he uses for Roman Catholics) have maintained that the temporal power has no jurisdiction over them, and that the spiritual power is above the temporal. This suggests that the "temporal power" refers to the authority of the state or secular government, which the Church claims should not have control over religious matters or the Church itself.

question:

O ye who believe! Strong drink and games of chance and idols… are only an infamy of Satan's handiwork. Leave it aside in order that ye may succeed.
the Qur'an, Sura 5: 89
When once you hear the roses are in bloom,

the Rubáiyát of Omar Khayyám

pred:
The answer to the question, based on the provided verses from the Qur'an and the Rubáiyát of Omar Khayyám, would best support the conclusion that:

(A) Religious restrictions were not universally observed by all Muslims.

Explanation:

- The Qur'anic verse (Sura 5: 89) explicitly advises Muslims to avoid strong drink, games of chance, and idols, categorizing them as "an infamy of Satan's handiwork" and urging them to leave these behind in order to succeed.

- In contrast, the Rubáiyát of Omar Khayyám, a collection of quatrains by the Persian poet Omar Khayyám, celebrates the beauty of life and the moment, including the act of pouring wine when roses bloom. This poem does not align with the Qur'anic prohibition against strong drink and games of chance.

- The juxtaposition of these two texts highlights a divergence in attitudes toward religious restrictions and indulgence in pleasures. While the Qur'an imposes a clear prohibition, the Rubáiyát embraces the sensual and the ephemeral, suggesting that not all Muslims strictly adhered to these prohibitions.

- This comparison supports the conclusion that religious restrictions, particularly concerning strong drink and games of chance, were not universally observed by all Muslims. Some, like the intellectual represented by Omar Khayyám's poetry, may have embraced a more libertine or secular perspective, in contrast to the strictures of their faith.

- Option (B) "Muslim intellectuals were generally hostile to traditional religious practice" is not supported by the comparison. While Omar Khayyám's poetry does not align with the Qur'anic prohibitions, it does not necessarily indicate hostility towards traditional religious practice. It merely suggests a different perspective or lifestyle choice that coexisted with more devout adherence to Islamic teachings.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
"The real grievance of the worker is the insecurity of his existence; he is not sure that he will always have work, he is not sure that he will always be healthy, and he foresees that he will one day be old and unfit to work. If he falls into poverty, even if only through a prolonged illness, he is then completely helpless, exam_ins to his own devices, and society does not currently recognize any real obligation towards him beyond the usual help for the poor, even if he has been working all the time ever so faithfully and diligently. The usual help for the poor, however, leaves a lot to be desired, especially in large cities, where it is very much worse than in the country."
Otto von Bismarck, 1884
How would twentieth-century economist John Maynard Keynes suggest that society address Otto von Bismarck's evaluation of workers in Germany? (A) Keynes would recommend government intervention in order to maintain aggregate demand. (B) Keynes would advocate doing nothing because he felt poverty in rural areas was actually more severe than it was in cities.
pred:
The answer to the question is:

(A) Keynes would recommend government intervention in order to maintain aggregate demand.

Explanation:

John Maynard Keynes, a prominent economist of the twentieth century, is best known for his advocacy of government intervention in the economy to stabilize output and employment. His theories, which were developed in response to the Great Depression, emphasized the importance of aggregate demand in influencing economic activity.

Keynes believed that economic fluctuations were primarily due to changes in aggregate demand and that these fluctuations could be moderated by appropriate government policies. He suggested that during periods of economic downturns, when aggregate demand was insufficient to maintain full employment, governments should increase their spending or lower taxes to stimulate demand. This approach, known as fiscal policy, would help to maintain economic activity and provide employment opportunities for workers.

In the context of Otto von Bismarck's evaluation of workers in Germany, where he highlighted the insecurity of workers due to the lack of job security, health concerns, and the fear of future poverty especially during old age, Keynes would likely recommend government intervention to address these issues. This could include:

1. **Social Security Programs:** Establishing a system of social security where the government provides financial support to citizens during times of unemployment, illness, and retirement. This would help alleviate the insecurity that Bismarck highlighted.

2. **Unemployment Benefits:** Implementing unemployment insurance to provide financial assistance to workers who lose their jobs, helping them to maintain a basic standard of living until they can find new employment.

3. **Healthcare:** Expanding access to healthcare to ensure that workers and their families have access to medical services, reducing the financial burden of illness and injury.

4. **Public Works:** Initiating public works programs to ensure that there is always demand for labor, thus providing employment opportunities.

Keynes's approach would directly address Bismarck's concerns by advocating for a proactive role of the state in ensuring economic security for its citizens, thereby reducing the insecurity and potential poverty that Bismarck identified as significant issues for the working class. This aligns with Keynes's broader philosophy of using government intervention to manage the economy and promote stability and growth. 

Option (B) is incorrect because Keynes did not believe that poverty in rural areas was more severe than in cities or that doing nothing was an appropriate response to the issues highlighted by Bismarck. Keynes's economic theories were centered on the idea of active government intervention to manage economic cycles and promote full employment and economic stability.

The two texts best support which of the following conclusions? (A) Ancient Egyptians suffered under a more rigid social hierarchy than ancient Sumerians. (B) Ancient Egyptians had a less gloomy view of the afterlife than ancient Sumerians.
pred:

The Epic of Gilgamesh emphasizes the permanence and value of truth, suggesting that truth is a lasting principle that even those who do not know it can follow. It also portrays the House of Darkness as a place of darkness, dirt, and despair, where those who enter do not come out, and where dwellers live without light, food, or drink.

The Maxims of Ptahhotep, on the other hand, focus on moral guidance and the importance of following truth and righteousness. It suggests that those guided by the gods cannot lose their way and that those who transgress against the ordinances of truth will be punished. The text also implies a more optimistic view of the afterlife, where those who follow truth and righteousness will be able to cross the river of life successfully.

(B) Ancient Egyptians had a less gloomy view of the afterlife than ancient Sumerians.

question:

"When the gods fashioned Gilgamesh*, to him they gave a perfect form. The glorious sun Shamash bestowed upon him glory; Adad the terrible god of storms bestowed upon him courage. The great gods perfected his magnificence beyond all others, terrible like the great wild bull. Two thirds god they made him; one third man they made him.
Of Uruk, its great rampart he built, and the wall of the sacred Eanna temple, the holy sanctuary. Behold the outer walls which gleam with the brilliance of copper; see the inner wall which none might rival. Touch the threshold stone—it is from ancient days. Goest thou into the Eanna temple, yea, the dwelling place of Ishtar, the like of which no subsequent king or living man might equal. Ascend and walk about on the wall of Uruk, inspect the corner-stone, and examine its brick-work, whether its wall is not made of burned brick, and its foundation laid by the Seven Sages. One third for city, one third for garden, one third for field, and a precinct for the temple of Ishtar. These parts and the precinct comprise Uruk."
The Epic of Gilgamesh, ca. 2100 B.C.E.
*Gilgamesh was a king of Uruk.
Which of the following best describes the origins of epic poetry such as the Epic of Gilgamesh? (A) The rise of a literate class of scribes in cities who could record poems (B) The rise of a warrior elite whose deeds were worthy of praise and recording
pred:
The origins of epic poetry such as the Epic of Gilgamesh are best described by option (A): the rise of a literate class of scribes in cities who could record poems. This explanation is supported by several key points:

1. **Scribes and Writing**: The Epic of Gilgamesh, as well as other ancient epics like the Iliad and the Odyssey, were likely composed and transmitted orally before being written down. The development of cuneiform writing in ancient Mesopotamia around 3200 BCE and its subsequent refinement allowed for the recording of complex narratives like the Gilgamesh epic.

2. **Urban Centers**: The epic poetry often originates from or is associated with urban centers where a literate class of scribes existed. These scribes were responsible for administrative, legal, and literary tasks. The existence of a literate class is essential for the creation and preservation of written texts.

3. **Cultural and Religious Importance**: The epics often reflect the cultural and religious values of the societies in which they were created. The Epic of Gilgamesh, for example, deals with themes of heroism, mortality, and the quest for immortality, which would have been of great interest to the people of ancient Mesopotamia. The scribes, being well-versed in the culture and religion of their time, were the ones to capture and transmit these narratives.

4. **Oral Tradition**: Before being written down, these epics were likely part of an oral tradition, with bards and storytellers passing down the tales through generations. The scribes played a crucial role in fixing these oral traditions into a written form, ensuring their survival through time.

5. **Historical and Mythological Elements**: The epics often blend historical events with mythological elements, reflecting the complex societies they originate from. Scribes, being well-versed in both the mundane and the divine, were uniquely positioned to craft such narratives.

In summary, the rise of a literate class of scribes in cities is the most accurate explanation for the origins of epic poetry like the Epic of Gilgamesh, as it encompasses the necessary conditions for the creation, preservation, and transmission of these complex literary works.

Which of the following does the poem provide direct evidence for in its discussion of taxation in the third stanza? (A) The relatively high level of urbanization in Tang China (B) The Tang Dynasty's strong bureaucracy at the local level

The stanza also mentions that "The District Officers are demanding the land tax," which directly points to the existence of a strong bureaucratic system that enforces taxation. This system is part of the Tang Dynasty's governance structure, which, while effective in many ways, also imposed heavy burdens on the peasantry.

The poem does not provide direct evidence for (A) the relatively high level of urbanization in Tang China or (B) the Tang Dynasty's strong bureaucracy at the local level, as these points are not explicitly discussed in the stanza in question. The focus is on the hardships faced by farmers due to taxation and conscription, rather than on broader aspects of Tang Dynasty society or administration.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
"When the Portuguese go from Macao in China to Japan, they carry much white silk, gold, musk, and porcelain: and they bring from Japan nothing but silver. They have a great carrack which goes there every year and she brings from there every year about six hundred coins: and all this silver of Japan, and two hundred thousand coins more in silver which they bring yearly out of India, they employ to their great advantage in China: and they bring from there gold, musk, silk, copper, porcelains, and many other things very costly and gilded.
When the Portuguese come to Canton in China to traffic, they must remain there but certain days: and when they come in at the gate of the city, they must enter their names in a book, and when they go out at night they must put out their names. They may not lie in the town all night, but must lie in their boats outside of the town. And, their time expired, if any man remains there, he is imprisoned."
Ralph Fitch, an account of his travels to the Far East, 1599 C.E.
In addition to the sources of silver mentioned in the first paragraph, the greatest volume of additional silver came to China from which of the following regions? (A) The New World (B) The Middle East
pred:
The greatest volume of additional silver that came to China, apart from Japan and India, was from The New World. This silver influx significantly impacted the Chinese economy and trade dynamics during the 16th and 17th centuries, a period marked by the Spanish and Portuguese colonization of the Americas.

The Spanish conquest of the Aztec and Inca empires in the early 16th century led to the massive extraction of silver from mines in present-day Mexico and Peru. This silver was then transported to Europe, with a substantial portion being used to pay for goods in Asia, including China. The Portuguese, as mentioned in Ralph Fitch's account, played a crucial role in this trade by bringing silver from Japan and India to China, but the bulk of the silver that flooded into China from the Americas was far greater.

This influx of silver had profound effects on China's economy, contributing to inflation and the devaluation of copper coins, which were the primary medium of exchange in China at the time. The search for silver also intensified trade imbalances, as China became a major importer of silver, while Europe and Japan, the primary sources of this silver, accumulated Chinese goods in return. This dynamic helped shape the economic and trade policies of the Ming Dynasty and influenced the subsequent Qing Dynasty's efforts to regulate and control the silver trade.

question:

But the decline of Rome was the natural and inevitable effect of immoderate greatness. Prosperity ripened the principle of decay; the causes of destruction multiplied with the extent of conquest; and, as soon as time or accident had removed the artificial supports, the stupendous fabric yielded to the pressure of its own weight. . . . The victorious legions, who, in distant wars, acquired the vices of strangers and mercenaries, first oppressed the freedom of the republic, and afterwards violated the majesty of the purple.
