"In the days of a great struggle against a foreign enemy who has been endeavoring for three years to enslave our country, it pleased God to send Russia a further painful trial. Internal troubles threatened to have a fatal effect on the further progress of this obstinate war. The destinies of Russia, the honor of her heroic Army, the happiness of the people, and the whole future of our beloved country demand that the war should be conducted at all costs to a victorious end.

In these decisive days in the life of Russia we have thought that we owed to our people the close union and organization of all its forces for the realization of a rapid victory; for which reason, in agreement with the Imperial Duma, we have recognized that it is for the good of the country that we should abdicate the Crown of the Russian State and lay down the Supreme Power."
Tsar Nicholas II, Abdication, March 15, 1917

"History will not forgive revolutionaries for procrastinating when they could be victorious today (and they certainly will be victorious today), while they risk losing much tomorrow, in fact, the risk losing everything.

- **Resentment of the working classes:** The text also indicates that internal troubles, which are likely referring to the growing discontent among the working classes and other groups, are threatening to have a "fatal effect" on the war effort. In contrast, (B) Persecution of religious minorities is not mentioned as a reason for the abdication in the text from Source 1. While religious persecution was indeed a problem in Russia at the time, it is not the primary reason given for the abdication in this source.

Source 2, from Vladimir Lenin, provides a different context. question:

Every two months His Majesty sends from Lima 60,000 pesos to pay for the mita of the Indians. Up on the Huanacavelica range there are 3,000 or 4,000 Indians working in the mercury mine, with picks and hammers, breaking up the ore. And when they have filled up their little sacks, the poor fellows, loaded down, climb up those ladders and rigging, so distressing that a man can hardly get up them. That is the way they work in this mine, with many lights and the loud noise of the pounding and great confusion. Nor is that the greatest evil; that is due to thievish and undisciplined superintendents. According to His Majesty's warrant, the mine owners at Potosí have a right to the mita of 13,300 Indians. These mita Indians earn each day 4 reals. Besides these there are others not under obligation, who hire themselves out voluntarily: these each get from 12 to 16 reals, and some up to 24, according to how well they wield their picks or their reputation for knowing how to get the ore out.
Antonio Vasquez de Espinosa, report on mining in Huanacavelica and Potosí, 1620s
The third principal reason the local Yakut and Tungus natives are ruined is that from the time they first came under Russian control, they have been forced to pay yasak tribute. Some have paid in sables, others in red foxes, still others in cash. At first there were plenty of furbearing animals there, but now there are no sables and not many foxes in those lands, from the shores of the Arctic Ocean all the way south to the great Lena River. Moreover, almost half the natives cannot hunt because they no longer have horses, many of which have been pawned to the yasak collectors.
Heinrich von Füch, "On the Treatment of Natives in Northeast Siberia," 1744
The system of labor described in the first passage came into being in which of the following ways? (A) Spanish authorities adapted local forms of labor mobilization for their own purposes. (B) Spain refused to purchase slaves from Africa, relying instead on native American labor.
pred: The system of labor described in the first passage came into being as a result of the Spanish authorities adapting local forms of labor mobilization for their own purposes. This is indicated by the reference to the mita of the Indians, which was a labor draft system that the Spanish implemented in the Americas, particularly in the Andes. The mita required indigenous people to work in mines and other public works for a certain period, typically two years, as a form of tribute or tax. This system was a direct adaptation of the mita system that already existed in the Inca Empire before the Spanish conquest, but it was repurposed and expanded by the Spanish to exploit the indigenous labor force for their own economic benefit, particularly in the extraction of precious metals like mercury and silver. This practice was part of the broader colonial exploitation of native labor and resources in the Spanish Americas.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
At the peak of their power, the domains of the Mongol khans, or rulers, made up a vast realm in which once-hostile peoples lived together in peace and virtually all religions were tolerated. . . . The law code first promulgated by Chinggis Khan ordered human interaction. The result was an important new stage in international contact. From eastern Europe to southern China, merchants and travelers could move across the well-policed Mongol domains without fear for their lives or property. The great swath of Mongol territory that covered or connected most of Europe, Asia, and the Middle East served as a bridge between the civilizations of the Eastern Hemisphere. The caravans and embassies that crossed the Mongol lands transmitted new food, inventions, and ideas from one civilized pool to others and from civilized pools to the nomadic peoples who served as intermediaries. Secure trade routes made for prosperous merchants and wealthy, cosmopolitan cities. question:
This question refers to the following information.
"Thereupon it was declared by the above-mentioned representatives of the aforesaid King and Queen of Castile, Leon, Aragon, Sicily, Granada, etc., and of the aforesaid King of Portugal and the Algarves, etc.:
[I.] That, whereas a certain controversy exists between the said lords, their constituents, as to what lands, of all those discovered in the ocean sea up to the present day, the date of this treaty, pertain to each one of the said parts respectively; therefore, for the sake of peace and concord, and for the preservation of the relationship and love of the said King of Portugal for the said King and Queen of Castile, Aragon, etc., it being the pleasure of their Highnesses, they, their said representatives, acting in their name and by virtue of their powers herein described, covenanted and agreed that a boundary or straight line be determined and drawn north and south, from pole to pole, on the said ocean sea, from the Arctic to the Antarctic pole. This boundary or line shall be drawn straight, as aforesaid, at a distance of three hundred and seventy leagues west of the Cape Verde Islands, being calculated by degrees, or by any other manner as may be considered the best and readiest, provided the distance shall be no greater than abovesaid. And all lands, both islands and mainlands, found and discovered already, or to be found and discovered hereafter, by the said King of Portugal and by his vessels on this side of the said line and bound determined as above, toward the east, in either north or south latitude, on the eastern side of the said bound provided the said bound is not crossed, shall belong to, and remain in the possession of, and pertain forever to, the said King of Portugal and his successors. And all other lands, both islands and mainlands, found or to be found hereafter, discovered or to be discovered hereafter, which have been discovered or shall be discovered by the said King and Queen of Castile, Aragon, etc., and by their vessels, on the western side of the said bound, determined as above, after having passed the said bound toward the west, in either its north or south latitude, shall belong to, and remain in the possession of, and pertain forever to, the said King and Queen of Castile, Leon, etc., and to their successors."
Treaty of Tordesillas, 1494
Which of the following historical developments provides the best context for the treaty above? (A) European maritime exploration (B) The Protestant Reformation
pred:
The Treaty of Tordesillas (1494) is a historical document that provides the best context for the treaty above. This treaty was a pivotal agreement between the Catholic monarchs of Spain (King Ferdinand II of Aragon and Queen Isabella I of Castile) and King John II of Portugal. It was signed on June 7, 1494, in the Spanish town of Tordesillas to resolve a dispute arising from the voyages of Christopher Columbus to the New World in 1492 and subsequent Spanish and Portuguese explorations.

The treaty established a meridian line (later known as the Line of Demarcation) 370 leagues (approximately 1,185 miles or 1,925 kilometers) west of the Cape Verde Islands. This line divided the newly discovered lands outside Europe between Spain and Portugal. Lands discovered to the east of the line would belong to Portugal, and those to the west would belong to Spain. This division was intended to prevent conflict and to allocate newly discovered territories based on the principle of "first come, first served."

The context of European maritime exploration and the race for new territories in the Americas and other parts of the world is crucial for understanding the Treaty of Tordesillas. The treaty was a significant diplomatic and legal instrument of the time, reflecting the competitive spirit of European nations in their quest for global dominance and the wealth that new lands promised.

The other options, such as the Protestant Reformation (B), do not provide the correct context for the treaty. The Protestant Reformation, which began in 1517 with Martin Luther's Ninety-Five Theses, was a religious and political movement within Europe that led to the creation of Protestant churches and a major schism within Christianity. While the Reformation had profound effects on European politics, society, and culture, it does not directly relate to the context of the Treaty of Tordesillas, which was primarily about the division of newly discovered lands and the balance of power between Spain and Portugal.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
Know the self to be sitting in the chariot, the body to be the chariot, the intellect the charioteer, and the mind the reins. He who has understanding, who is mindful and always pure, indeed reaches that place from whence he is not born again.
from the Upanishads, India, circa 600s–400s B.C.E.
Which of the following changes to Indian religious practice took place under the Mauryan emperor Ashoka? (A) The official encouragement of Buddhist edicts (B) The rise of Sikhism as a syncretic faith
pred:
The correct answer to the question, based on the provided information from the Upanishads, is (A) The official encouragement of Buddhist edicts under the Mauryan emperor Ashoka.

Explanation:
The passage from the Upanishads describes a metaphorical understanding of the self and the journey towards liberation or enlightenment. It uses the imagery of a chariot, with the self as the passenger, the body as the chariot, the intellect as the charioteer, and the mind as the reins. The key to reaching the destination from which one is not reborn (liberation) is understanding, mindfulness, and purity of mind.

Ashoka's reign marked a significant turning point in Indian religious history, particularly for Buddhism. After the Kalinga War, Ashoka converted to Buddhism and became a fervent supporter and propagator of the faith. He is famously known for commissioning the Edicts of Ashoka, which were inscriptions on rocks and pillars throughout the Mauryan empire. These edicts officially encouraged Buddhist teachings and principles, promoting non-violence (ahimsa), Dharma (righteousness), and the importance of being kind to all living beings.

Ashoka's support for Buddhism and the dissemination of its teachings significantly impacted Indian religious practice, making Buddhism a state-supported religion and spreading its influence across Asia. This official encouragement of Buddhist edicts under Ashoka's rule aligns with option (A) and represents a pivotal change in Indian religious history.

Option (B) The rise of Sikhism as a syncretic faith, while historically significant, occurred much later than Ashoka's time (in the 15th century), and it was not initiated under Ashoka's rule. Therefore, it does not accurately describe a change that took place under Ashoka's influence.

question:

The Bahr [al-Fava'id, or "Sea of Precious Virtues," written in the 1150s or 1160s] insists that the first duty of a Muslim ruler is to prosecute the jihad and bring about the victory of Islam, and if he does not do so and he makes peace with the infidel, that ruler would be better dead than alive, for he would be corrupting the world.
Robert Irwin, "Islam and the Crusades," 1995

(B) showing how, in the Middle East during the crusading era, economic factors trumped all other considerations.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
"In Northern India the existence of separate States at this period is usually little more than a question of words. A zamindar who paid revenue to the Mogul was clearly in a position of dependence, and if he wished to establish a claim to sovereignty, the first step was to refuse, or omit to pay revenue. Such an omission might, however, arise from various other causes, and it is probable that in Rajputana, Central India, and Chota Nagpur there were numerous chiefs and tribes occupying what constitutional lawyers would regard as an anomalous position, sometimes paying the stipulated revenue, sometimes in open rebellion, and sometimes enjoying practical independence because the Mogul authorities found it inconvenient to undertake active measures of coercion."
W.H. Moreland, India at the Death of Akbar, 1920
Moreland's description of revenue collection in the Mughal Empire is best seen as evidence for which of the following generalizations? (A) Geographical differences may have influenced which groups pay taxes. (B) The case of Rajputana was a typical one in the Mughal Empire.
pred:
The answer to the question, based on the provided information from W.H. Moreland's "India at the Death of Akbar" (1920), is best summarized as:

(A) Geographical differences may have influenced which groups pay taxes.

Explanation: Moreland's description highlights that in Northern India, the existence of separate states was often nominal, with zamindars (landlords) paying revenue to the Mughal Empire, indicating a position of dependence. However, to establish a claim to sovereignty, a zamindar would first refuse to pay revenue. This omission could arise from various causes, suggesting that the ability to claim independence or practical sovereignty was not uniform across the region. The mention of Rajputana, Central India, and Chota Nagpur indicates that different regions had varying degrees of autonomy and compliance with Mughal authority, influenced by factors such as convenience for the Mughal authorities to enforce their rule. This variability in the relationship between local leaders and the Mughal Empire suggests that geographical location played a significant role in determining the degree of tax payment and autonomy, thereby supporting the generalization that geographical differences influenced which groups paid taxes.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
Source 1:
"We proclaim Him also by our senses on all sides, and we sanctify the noblest sense, which is that of sight. The image is a memorial, just what words are to a listening ear. What a book is to the literate, that an image is to the illiterate. The image speaks to the sight as words to the ear; it brings us understanding."
John of Damascus, Apologia Against Those Who Decry Holy Images, ca. 730 C.E.
Source 2:
"To make our confession short, we keep unchanged all the ecclesiastical traditions handed down to us, whether in writing or verbally, one of which is the making of pictorial representations, agreeable to the history of the preaching of the Gospel, a tradition useful in many respects, but especially in this, that so the incarnation of the Word of God is shown forth as real and not merely fantastic, for these have mutual indications and without doubt have also mutual significations."
Decree of the Second Council of Nicaea, 787 C.E.
The late eighth-century religious debate in Byzantium that occasioned the writing of the passages is best understood in the context of which of the following? (A) Disagreement about the appropriate use of religious iconography (B) Disagreement about the best form of ascetic practice
pred:
The late eighth-century religious debate in Byzantium that is best understood in the context of the passages from John of Damascus and the Second Council of Nicaea was primarily about (A) Disagreement about the appropriate use of religious iconography.

John of Damascus's "Apologia Against Those Who Decry Holy Images" defends the use of religious iconography, comparing images to memorials and books, emphasizing their role in teaching and conveying religious truths visually to those who cannot read. He argues that images serve a similar function to words for the illiterate, helping them to understand and internalize religious teachings.

The Decree of the Second Council of Nicaea (787 C.E.) confirms the legitimacy and continued use of pictorial representations (icons) within the Christian tradition. This council's decision was a significant victory for those who supported the veneration of icons, countering the earlier Iconoclastic Controversy (726-787 C.E.) where some factions had condemned the use of icons as idolatrous.

This controversy was indeed about disagreement regarding the appropriate use of religious iconography. On one side, iconoclasts (those who were against icons) argued that the use of images constituted idolatry and was contrary to the commandment against making graven images. On the other side, the supporters of icons, like John of Damascus and the Second Council of Nicaea, argued that icons were a legitimate and valuable means of worship and education within the Christian faith, serving as visual aids to the teachings of the Gospel and helping believers to venerate and contemplate the divine.

Thus, the late eighth-century religious debate in Byzantium was fundamentally about the appropriate use of religious iconography, with the sources provided reflecting the positions of those who supported the veneration of icons.

question:

By what principle of reason then, should these foreigners send in return a poisonous drug? Without meaning to say that the foreigners harbor such destructive intentions in their hearts, we yet positively assert that from their inordinate thirst after gain, they are perfectly careless about the injuries they inflict upon us! And such being the case, we should like to ask what has become of that conscience which heaven has implanted in the breasts of all men? We have heard that in your own country opium is prohibited with the utmost strictness and severity. This is a strong proof that you know full well how hurtful it is to mankind. Since you do not permit it to injure your own country, you ought not to have this injurious drug transferred to another country, and above all others, how much less to the Inner Land! Of the products which China exports to your foreign countries, there is not one which is not beneficial to mankind in some shape or other.
Lin Zexu, Chinese trade commissioner, letter to Queen Victoria, 1839
The passage is most closely related with which of the following broad developments? (A) Europe's economic domination of China (B) Europe's colonization of Chinese territory
pred:
The passage by Lin Zexu is most closely related to the broad development of (A) Europe's economic domination of China. Lin Zexu's letter to Queen Victoria in 1839 was a protest against the British trade of opium in China, which was a significant aspect of Europe's economic influence over China during the 19th century. This period is often referred to as the "Century of Humiliation" for China, as the country faced increasing incursions and economic exploitation by Western powers, including Britain.

Lin Zexu's letter specifically addresses the trade of opium, which was a highly lucrative business for the British East India Company. The opium trade was a major source of revenue for Britain and contributed to its economic dominance over China. The letter reflects China's attempt to resist and protest against this economic exploitation and the negative impact of opium on Chinese society.

The other option, (B) Europe's colonization of Chinese territory, is not directly addressed in Lin Zexu's letter. While European powers did engage in colonization and territorial expansion in other parts of the world, the letter focuses on the economic issue of the opium trade and does not mention any plans for colonization in China. Thus, the correct answer is (A) Europe's economic domination of China.

question:

"Al-Zawawi also said 'This sultan Musa told me that at a town called ZKRY he has a copper mine from which ingots are brought to BYTY. "There is nothing in my kingdom, Musa said, on which a duty is levied except this crude copper which is brought in. Duty is collected on this and on nothing else. We send it to the land of the pagan Sudan and sell it for two-thirds of its weight in gold, so that we sell 100 measures of this copper for 66 2/3 measures of gold.' He also stated that there are pagan nations in his kingdom from whom he does not collect the tribute (jizya) but whom he simply employs in extracting the gold from its deposits. The gold is extracted by digging pits about a man's height in depth and the gold is found embedded in the sides of the pits or sometimes collected at the bottom of them."
From N. Levtzion & J.F.P. Hopkins, eds. Corpus of Early
Arabic Sources for West African History. Cambridge
University Press, 1981. Reprinted with permission of
Cambridge University Press.
Al' Umari, ca. 1300–1384
Which of the following inferences is most supported by the discussion of copper and gold in the passage? (A) International trade with Sub-Saharan Africa involved the exchange of mineral resources. (B) Mali's relatively advanced mining technologies accounted for its mineral wealth.
pred:
The passage from Al-Zawawi, as recorded by Al-Umari, describes the operations of Sultan Musa in relation to copper and gold extraction and trade. It indicates that:

1. **Copper Mining and Trade**: Sultan Musa has a copper mine in a place called ZKRY, from which ingots are brought to BYTY. The copper is the only commodity on which a duty is levied, suggesting it is a significant source of revenue.

2. **Gold Trade**: The gold is extracted through mining operations described as digging pits to a man's height and finding gold embedded in the sides or at the bottom. The gold is then sold for two-thirds of its weight in gold, indicating a lucrative trade.

3. **International Trade**: The copper is sold to pagan Sudanese nations for gold, indicating a form of international trade where copper is exchanged for gold.

From these points, the most supported inference is:

**A) International trade with Sub-Saharan Africa involved the exchange of mineral resources.**

This inference is supported by the details provided in the passage:

- The copper is being traded for gold.
- The copper is being transported to BYTY, which suggests a network of trade routes.
- The trade partners are described as pagan Sudanese nations, indicating a specific region of Sub-Saharan Africa.

The passage does not provide evidence for:

**B) Mali's relatively advanced mining technologies accounted for its mineral wealth.**

While the passage does describe mining practices, it does not attribute these practices specifically to Mali or suggest that Mali's mining technologies were particularly advanced. The passage focuses on the operations of Sultan Musa and does not provide information about the broader technological or organizational capabilities of Mali's mining industry. Additionally, the passage does not explicitly state that the location of ZKRY and BYTY is within Mali or that the operations described were conducted by Malian authorities.

Therefore, the most supported inference based on the passage is that international trade involving mineral resources (copper) was a significant aspect of economic activity in the region, with gold being a primary commodity in exchange.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
O ye who believe! Strong drink and games of chance and idols… are only an infamy of Satan's handiwork. Leave it aside in order that ye may succeed.
the Qur'an, Sura 5: 89
When once you hear the roses are in bloom,
Then is the time, my love, to pour the wine.
the Rubáiyát of Omar Khayyám
The tone of the first verse best reflects which of the following modes of religious discourse? (A) A puritanical injunction to adhere to a strict code of conduct (B) A spirited attempt to convert non-believers
pred:
The answer to the question is:

(A) A puritanical injunction to adhere to a strict code of conduct

Explanation:

The first verse from the Qur'an (Sura 5: 89) is a directive from Allah to believers, commanding them to abstain from strong drink, games of chance, and idolatry. This verse is part of a broader context in the Qur'an that emphasizes obedience to God and avoidance of practices that are considered sinful or distracting from the path of righteousness. The tone of this verse is cautionary and prescriptive, urging believers to distance themselves from activities that are deemed as "an infamy of Satan's handiwork" in order to "succeed" in a spiritual sense.

In contrast, the second verse from the Rubáiyát of Omar Khayyám is a poetic expression of the enjoyment of life and the fleeting nature of time, as symbolized by the blooming of roses and the drinking of wine. It reflects a more secular and hedonistic perspective, celebrating the pleasures of the moment rather than adhering to a strict moral or religious code.

The Qur'anic verse is thus best described as a puritanical injunction, as it seeks to prescribe a specific behavior (avoidance of certain activities) in order to align with a strict religious code of conduct. This mode of religious discourse is about setting guidelines for believers to follow in order to live a life that is pleasing to God and to avoid the temptations of Satan.

The Rubáiyát verse, on the other hand, does not fit neatly into the category of religious discourse but rather falls into the realm of secular poetry, reflecting a more philosophical and existential view of life and the enjoyment of its pleasures. It does not advocate for a strict adherence to religious rules but instead encourages the reader to appreciate the transient beauty of life and to indulge in its pleasures.

question:

Whether the question be to continue or to discontinue the practice of sati, the decision is equally surrounded by an awful responsibility. To consent to the consignment year after year of hundreds of innocent victims to a cruel and untimely end, when the power exists of preventing it, is a predicament which no conscience can contemplate without horror. But, on the other hand, to put to hazard by a contrary course the very safety of the British Empire in India is an alternative which itself may be considered a still greater evil. William Bentinck, Govenor-General of India, "On the Suppression of Sati," 1829

question:
This question refers to the following information.
Source 1:
"In the days of a great struggle against a foreign enemy who has been endeavoring for three years to enslave our country, it pleased God to send Russia a further painful trial. Internal troubles threatened to have a fatal effect on the further progress of this obstinate war. The destinies of Russia, the honor of her heroic Army, the happiness of the people, and the whole future of our beloved country demand that the war should be conducted at all costs to a victorious end.
The cruel enemy is making his last efforts and the moment is near when our valiant Army, in concert with our glorious Allies, will finally overthrow the enemy. In these decisive days in the life of Russia we have thought that we owed to our people the close union and organization of all its forces for the realization of a rapid victory; for which reason, in agreement with the Imperial Duma, we have recognized that it is for the good of the country that we should abdicate the Crown of the Russian State and lay down the Supreme Power."
Tsar Nicholas II, Abdication, March 15, 1917
Source 2:
"History will not forgive revolutionaries for procrastinating when they could be victorious today (and they certainly will be victorious today), while they risk losing much tomorrow, in fact, the risk losing everything.
If we seize power today, we seize it not in opposition to the Soviets but on their behalf. The seizure of power is the business of the uprising; its political purpose will become clear after the seizure….
It would be an infinite crime on the part of the revolutionaries were they to let the chance slip, knowing that the salvation of the revolution, the offer of peace, the salvation of Petrograd, salvation from famine, the transfer of the land to the peasants depend upon them.
The government is tottering. It must be given the death-blow at all costs."
Vladimir Illyich Lenin, Call to Power, October 24, 1917
What was the principal philosophical underpinning of Lenin's call to power in Source 2? (A) Marxism (B) Capitalism
pred:
The principal philosophical underpinning of Lenin's call to power in Source 2 is Marxism. Lenin's call emphasizes the need for the revolutionaries to seize power immediately, as they have the opportunity to do so successfully today, rather than waiting and risking losing the chance. He frames the revolution as a necessary step for the salvation of the revolution, the offer of peace, and the welfare of the people, which aligns with Marxist principles that advocate for the overthrow of the capitalist system by the proletariat to establish a socialist state as a precursor to communism.

Lenin's statement reflects Marxist ideology in several ways:

1. **Immediate Action**: Lenin's insistence on immediate action is a key tenet of Marxist thought, which posits that the proletariat must act decisively to overthrow the capitalist system before it can fully consolidate its power and establish a socialist state.

2. **Class Struggle**: Lenin's reference to the "salvation of the revolution" and the "offer of peace" underscores the Marxist notion of class struggle, where the working class (proletariat) must rise up against the capitalist class (bourgeoisie) to achieve liberation and establish a more equitable society.

3. **Historical Materialism**: Lenin's emphasis on the present moment as a critical juncture for revolution reflects the Marxist concept of historical materialism, which argues that societal development is driven by economic factors and that revolutionary change is inevitable as economic contradictions within capitalism reach a breaking point.

4. **Dictatorship of the Proletariat**: Lenin's call for the revolutionaries to seize power is in line with the Marxist idea of the "dictatorship of the proletariat," a transitional stage where the working class establishes a temporary, revolutionary government to dismantle the capitalist system and build socialism.

In contrast, Lenin's call to power is not rooted in capitalism but directly opposes it, advocating for a radical transformation of society based on Marxist principles. Therefore, the correct answer to the question is (A) Marxism.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
The following poem refers to an incident in Sharpeville, South Africa, in 1960. To protest the requirement that they carry papers documenting their identity and residence, black South Africans gathered in front of police stations without their papers. Though other protests ended peacefully, in Sharpeville, police fired into the crowd.
What is important
about Sharpeville
is not that seventy died:
nor even that they were shot in the back
retreating, unarmed, defenceless
and certainty not
the heavy caliber slug
that tore through a mother's back
and ripped through the child in her arms
killing it
Remember Sharpeville
bullet-in-the-back day
Because it epitomized oppression
and the nature of society
More clearly than anything else;
it was the classic event
Nowhere is racial dominance
more clearly defined
nowhere the will to oppress
more clearly demonstrated
What the world whispers
apartheid declares with snarling guns
the blood the rich lust after
South Africa spills dust
Remember Sharpeville
Remember bullet-in-the-back day
And remember the unquenchable will for freedom
Remember the dead
and be glad
—Dennis Brutus, 1973
What event symbolized the end of South Africa's institutionalized discrimination? (A) The election of Nelson Mandela (B) The election of F. W. de Klerk
pred: The event that symbolized the end of South Africa's institutionalized discrimination was the election of Nelson Mandela (Option A). Mandela's election as the first black president of South Africa in 1994 marked a significant turning point in the country's history, leading to the dismantling of apartheid and the establishment of a democratic government. This event signified the triumph of the anti-apartheid movement and the will of the South African people for equality and freedom, as epitomized by the Sharpeville massacre and the broader struggle against racial oppression.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
The city of Ghana consists of two towns. One is inhabited by Muslims and has twelve mosques, salaried imams and muezzins, and jurists and scholars. In the environs are wells with sweet water, from which they drink and with which they grow vegetables. . . . The king's interpreters, the official in charge of his treasury and the majority of his ministers are Muslims. Only royalty may wear sewn clothes. All other people wear robes of cotton, silk, or brocade, according to their means. . . . The king adorns himself like a woman, wearing necklaces round his neck and bracelets on his forearms. . . . He sits . . . in a domed pavilion around which stand ten horses. When people who profess the same religion as the king approach him they fall on their knees and sprinkle dust on their heads, for this is their way of greeting him. As for the Muslims, they greet him only by clapping their hands. [The people's] religion is paganism and the worship of idols. . . . On every donkey-load of salt when it is brought into the country their king levies one golden dinar, and two dinars when it is sent out. From a load of copper the king's due is five mithqals, and from a load of other goods ten mithqals. . . . The nuggets found in all the mines of his country are reserved for the king, only this gold dust being left for the people. But for this the people would accumulate gold until it lost its value. Beyond this country lies another called Malal, the king of which was sincerely attached to Islam, while the common people of his kingdom remained polytheists. Since then their rulers have been given the title of al-musulmani .
—The Book of Routes and Realms , by Abu Ubaydallah al-Bakri, eleventh-century Muslim historian and geographer
Based on the excerpt, which of the following statements correctly describes Islam's influence in Africa during this time period? (A) Some elites converted to Islam, but lower classes kept their traditional beliefs. (B) African kings required Muslims to conform to pagan customs at court.
pred:
Based on the excerpt from Abu Ubaydallah al-Bakri's "The Book of Routes and Realms," Islam's influence in Africa during this time period can be described as follows:

(A) Some elites converted to Islam, but lower classes kept their traditional beliefs.

This statement correctly captures the essence of Islam's influence in the described African city and the neighboring kingdom of Malal. The letters collectively illustrate the early stages of the transatlantic slave trade, where European powers, including Portugal, sought to exploit the labor and resources of African kingdoms like Kongo. question:

"After the Tencteri came, in former days, the Bructeri; but the general account now is, that the Chamavi and Angrivarii entered their settlements, drove them out and utterly exterminated them with the common help of the [neighboring] tribes, either from hatred of their tyranny, or from the attractions of plunder, or from heaven's [favorable] regard for us. pred:

This act of violence and displacement is a form of treatment of barbarian peoples by civilized societies that has occurred throughout history from 600 B.C.E. to 1450 C.E.

The treatment described in the passage aligns with option (A): "Barbarian peoples were utilized as soldiers in their host societies." This is because the passage suggests that the Chamavi and Angrivarii were not only driven out the Bructeri but also exterminated them, which implies a form of military conquest and dominance over the conquered tribe. While option (B) "Barbarian peoples were converted to the religions of their host societies" is also a significant historical phenomenon, it is not the primary focus of Tacitus's passage. The passage does not explicitly mention religious conversion as the main treatment of the barbarian peoples by the civilized societies. Instead, the emphasis is on the violent expulsion and extermination of the Bructeri by the Chamavi and Angrivarii, which is more aligned with the theme of military and territorial conquest.

Therefore, the answer to the question is (A): Barbarian peoples were utilized as soldiers in their host societies. This reflects a common historical pattern where more powerful societies incorporated or eliminated less powerful ones, often using them as soldiers or laborers within the conquering society.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
"MAHATMA GANDHI'S MESSAGE.
REMAIN NON-VIOLENT
The following message was sent by Mahatma Gandhi from Waltair:—
Maulana Mohamed AH was arrested at Waltair under sections 107 and 108 to be called upon to give security, to be of good behaviour for one year. The place and date of trial is unknown.
The Begum Saheba and Mr. Hayat were permitted to see him after arrest.
He and I were going to address a meeting outside the station. He was arrested. I continued going to the meeting and addressed them. There is no cause for sorrow, but every cause for congratulation. There should be no hartal. Perfect peace and calmness should be observed. I regard the arrest as a prelude to Swaraj and the redress of the Khilafat and the Punjab wrongs, if we can remain non-violent. Retain Hindu-Muslim Unity despite the madness of some Moplahs, and fulfil the Swadeshi programme.
I hope every Indian, man or woman, will completely boycott foreign cloth and take up spinning or weaving during every spare minute.
By striving like the Maulana, be insistent on religious and national rights.
Let us earn imprisonment. I am conscious of the Maulana's innocence and I am sure the imprisonment of the innocent will enable the nation to reach the cherished goal."
Mohandas Gandhi, The Pilgrims' March, 1921
Which of the following historical developments from the period 1450–1750 C.E. most inspired the instructions indicated in the fifth paragraph to boycott foreign cloth? (A) The African slave trade (B) The development of joint-stock companies
pred:
The historical development that most inspired Gandhi's instructions to boycott foreign cloth in the fifth paragraph is the (B) The development of joint-stock companies.

Explanation:
Gandhi's message emphasizes the importance of self-reliance and the boycott of foreign goods as a means to promote economic independence and strengthen the Indian economy. The development of joint-stock companies during the period 1450-1750 C.E. was a significant economic transformation that allowed for the pooling of capital and the formation of large trading companies. These companies played a crucial role in the expansion of European trade networks, including the establishment of trading empires that imported vast quantities of goods from the colonies, including textiles from India.

Gandhi's call for the boycott of foreign cloth was part of his broader strategy to encourage self-sufficiency and economic independence within India. By promoting the use of Indian-spun and woven cloth, he aimed to stimulate the local textile industry, which had been undermined by the influx of cheaper, machine-made textiles from Britain and other European countries. This strategy was part of a larger movement towards Swadeshi (self-made) goods, which sought to reduce dependence on foreign imports and bolster local industries.

Thus, the inspiration for Gandhi's instructions to boycott foreign cloth comes from the desire to counteract the economic dominance of foreign powers, particularly in the context of the British Empire's control over India's economy. The historical context of the rise of joint-stock companies, which facilitated the dominance of foreign trade and the importation of foreign goods, provided the backdrop for Gandhi's call for economic self-reliance and the promotion of Indian-made products.

question:

It was the best of times, it was the worst of times, it was the age of wisdom, it was the age of foolishness, it was the epoch of belief, it was the epoch of incredulity, it was the season of Light, it was the season of Darkness, it was the spring of hope, it was the winter of despair, we had everything before us, we had nothing before us, we were all going direct to Heaven, we were all going direct the other way—in short, the period was so far like the present period, that some of its noisiest authorities insisted on its being received, for good or for evil, in the superlative degree of comparison only.
There were a king with a large jaw and a queen with a plain face, on the throne of England; there were a king with a large jaw and a queen with a fair face, on the throne of France. In both countries it was clearer than crystal . . . that things in general were settled for ever.
—A Tale of Two Cities, by Charles Dickens
Bliss was it in that dawn to be alive. But to be young was very heaven.
—The Prelude, by William Wordsworth
Most revolutions produce a strong leading figure; the French Revolution allowed which of the following to assume great power? (A) Robespierre (B) Lafayette
pred:
The answer to the question, which revolves around the impact of the French Revolution and the roles of key figures like Robespierre and Lafayette, is Robespierre.

Explanation:
The French Revolution, as described by Charles Dickens in "A Tale of Two Cities" and alluded to by William Wordsworth in "The Prelude," was a period of significant upheaval and transformation. It was marked by the overthrow of the monarchy and the establishment of a republic, followed by the rise of radical factions and the Reign of Terror under leaders like Maximilien Robespierre.

Robespierre, a prominent figure during the Revolution, became a central authority and assumed great power. He was a leading member of the Jacobin Club and a driving force behind the Reign of Terror, a period of severe repression and purges that sought to eliminate perceived enemies of the Revolution. His influence and control over the revolutionary government were so significant that he was effectively the de facto ruler of France during this time.

In contrast, Lafayette, a hero of the American Revolution, was a moderate revolutionary who advocated for constitutional monarchy and the protection of individual rights. While he played a significant role in the early stages of the French Revolution, his influence waned as the Revolution became more radical, and he eventually fled France.

Given the context provided by Dickens and Wordsworth, the figure who assumed the greatest power during the French Revolution, embodying both the hope and the darkness of the period, was Robespierre. Therefore, the correct answer to the question is Robespierre (A).

The testimony mentions "jobs" and "factories," which are indicative of industrial work environments, and the reference to children receiving "3s. a week" (or 15 pence, which is a very small amount of money) for their labor also points to the exploitation common during the Industrial Revolution. The conditions described—moderate labor, lower wages, children working in poor conditions, and necessity compelling parents to allow their children to work—align with the historical realities of the Industrial Revolution. The other period mentioned, The Enlightenment, is a different era that focused on intellectual and philosophical developments rather than the economic and social changes associated with factory work and labor exploitation described in the passage. I don't know whether this world has meaning that transcends it. But I know that I do not know that meaning, and that it is impossible just now for me to know it. What can a meaning outside my condition mean to me? I can understand only in human terms.
Albert Camus, "The Myth of Sisyphus," 1955
The passage above is best seen as exemplifying which of the following intellectual trends? (A) A modernist tendency to question the validity of faith-based moralities (B) An increased willingness to embrace radical Marxism
pred: The passage by Albert Camus, "The Myth of Sisyphus," reflects a modernist tendency to question the validity of faith-based moralities. Camus' statement highlights his existentialist perspective, which emphasizes individual experience and the human condition over external, absolute meanings or values. He expresses a skepticism towards knowing a transcendent meaning and suggests that understanding must be confined to human terms, which aligns with modernist thought that often critiques traditional, faith-based moralities for their rigidity and lack of flexibility in addressing the complexities of modern life. Camus' work does not advocate for radical Marxism or any other specific ideology but rather focuses on the individual's confrontation with the absurdity of existence and the freedom that comes with accepting this absurdity. Therefore, the passage best exemplifies modernist tendencies rather than an increased willingness to embrace radical Marxism.

question:

"The case of a broken thigh is analogous to that of the arm, but in particular, a fractured thigh is mostly deranged forwards and outwards, for the bone is naturally flattened on those sides. It is to be set by the hands, with ligatures, and even cords applied, the one above and the other below the fracture. When the fracture takes place at one end, if at the head of the thigh, the middle part of a thong wrapped round with wool, so that it may not cut the parts there, is to be applied to the perineum, and the ends of it brought up to the head and given to an assistant to hold, and applying a ligature below the fracture, we give the ends of it to another assistant to make extension. If it is fractured near the knee, we apply the ligature immediately above the fracture, and give the ends to an assistant, with which to make extension upwards; and while we put a ligature round the knee to secure it, and while the patient lies thus, with his leg extended, we arrange the fracture."
Paul of Aegina, Epitome: On the Fracture of the Thigh and Nose, late seventh century C.E.
Source 2:
"Medicine considers the human body as to the means by which it is cured and by which it is driven away from health. The knowledge of anything, since all things have causes, is not acquired or complete unless it is known by its causes. Therefore in medicine we ought to know the causes of sickness and health. And because health and sickness and their causes are sometimes manifest, and sometimes hidden and not to be comprehended except by the study of symptoms, we must also study the symptoms of health and disease. Now it is established in the sciences that no knowledge is acquired save through the study of its causes and beginnings, if it has had causes and beginnings; nor completed except by knowledge of its accidents and accompanying essentials."
Ibn Sina (Avicenna), On Medicine, ca. 1020 C.E.
The two passages on medicine illustrate which of the following cultural exchanges that occurred in the period 600–1450 C.E.? (A) The influence of Greek science on Europeans through Byzantine and Islamic scholars (B) The influence of Chinese science on Islamic civilizations through European immigration to Islamic lands
pred:
The two passages provided, one from Paul of Aegina (late 7th century C.E.) and the other from Ibn Sina (Avicenna, ca. 1020 C.E.), illustrate the cultural exchange of medical knowledge primarily through the influence of Greek science on Islamic civilizations. This exchange is evident through the transmission of medical practices, theories, and treatments from ancient Greek medicine to Islamic scholars, who then expanded and systematized this knowledge.

Paul of Aegina's passage describes the treatment of thigh fractures, detailing the methods for setting the bone, which are reminiscent of the Hippocratic and Galenic medical traditions that were foundational to Greek medicine. These practices were later adopted and further developed by Islamic physicians.

Ibn Sina's passage emphasizes the importance of understanding the causes and symptoms of health and disease, a core principle of Greek medicine. He argues that medical knowledge should be based on the study of causes and symptoms, a concept that originates from Greek medical philosophy.

The cultural exchange between Greek science and Islamic civilizations is clear in these texts. This exchange did not involve Chinese science directly influencing Islamic civilizations through European immigration, as there is no historical evidence to support such a claim. Instead, the transmission of medical knowledge from Greek to Islamic scholars, and subsequently to Europe through Islamic contributions, is a well-documented and significant aspect of the cultural exchanges during the period 600–1450 C.E.

Therefore, the correct answer to the question is:

(A) The influence of Greek science on Europeans through Byzantine and Islamic scholars

By what principle of reason then, should these foreigners send in return a poisonous drug? Without meaning to say that the foreigners harbor such destructive intentions in their hearts, we yet positively assert that from their inordinate thirst after gain, they are perfectly careless about the injuries they inflict upon us! And such being the case, we should like to ask what has become of that conscience which heaven has implanted in the breasts of all men? We have heard that in your own country opium is prohibited with the utmost strictness and severity. This is a strong proof that you know full well how hurtful it is to mankind. Since you do not permit it to injure your own country, you ought not to have this injurious drug transferred to another country, and above all others, how much less to the Inner Land! Lin Zexu, Chinese trade commissioner, letter to Queen Victoria, 1839
Which of the following background facts persuaded Europeans to engage in the actions described in the passage? (A) The price of Chinese tea had risen higher than European buyers found acceptable. (B) China refused to allow a meaningful volume of European goods to be sold there.
pred:
The background fact that persuaded Europeans to engage in the actions described in the passage is:

(B) China refused to allow a meaningful volume of European goods to be sold there.

Explanation: Lin Zexu's letter to Queen Victoria in 1839 was written in protest against the British practice of smuggling opium into China. He accused the foreigners (Europeans) of being driven by greed and being indifferent to the harm they caused to China. He pointed out that Europeans prohibit opium in their own countries because they know how harmful it is, yet they continue to smuggle it into China. Lin Zexu's letter highlights China's refusal to allow a significant volume of European goods into the Chinese market as a key grievance. This trade imbalance and the refusal to allow European goods to be sold in China were significant factors that led to the First Opium War (1839-1842), as the Europeans sought to protect their economic interests and gain greater access to Chinese markets. The other options (A) and (C) do not directly relate to the actions described in the passage, which focus on the smuggling of opium and the broader issue of trade relations between China and Europe.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
"To slacken the tempo would mean falling behind. And those who fall behind get beaten. But we do not want to be beaten. No, we refuse to be beaten! One feature of the history of old Russia was the continual beatings she suffered because of her backwardness. She was beaten by the Mongol khans. She was beaten by the Turkish beys. She was beaten by the Swedish feudal lords. She was beaten by the Polish and Lithuanian gentry. She was beaten by the British and French capitalists. She was beaten by the Japanese barons. All beat her––because of her backwardness, because of her military backwardness, cultural backwardness, political backwardness, industrial backwardness, agricultural backwardness. They beat her because it was profitable and could be done with impunity. You remember the words of the pre-revolutionary poet: "You are poor and abundant, mighty and impotent, Mother Russia." Those gentlemen were quite familiar with the verses of the old poet. They beat her, saying: "You are abundant," so one can enrich oneself at your expense. They beat her, saying: "You are poor and impotent," so you can be beaten and plundered with impunity. Such is the law of the exploiters––to beat the backward and the weak. It is the jungle law of capitalism. You are backward, you are weak––therefore you are wrong; hence you can be beaten and enslaved. You are mighty––therefore you are right; hence we must be wary of you.
That is why we must no longer lag behind."
Joseph Stalin, speech delivered at the first All-Union Conference of Leading Personnel of Socialist Industry, February 4, 1931
Stalin's efforts to advance Russia as justified by his mention of the "continual beatings" were vindicated by which of the following historical events? (A) The Polish-Soviet War in the early 1920s (B) The German invasion of Russia in 1941
pred:
The answer to the question, which historical events vindicated Stalin's efforts to advance Russia by ending her "continual beatings," is the German invasion of Russia in 1941 (Option B).

Stalin's speech emphasized Russia's historical vulnerability to invasion and exploitation due to her backwardness. The German invasion during World War II (Operation Barbarossa, June 22, 1941) was a significant event that validated Stalin's concerns. The Soviet Union was indeed caught off guard and suffered massive losses initially, but ultimately, the Soviet military, under Stalin's leadership, turned the tide against the German forces. This event marked a pivotal moment in the war, leading to the eventual defeat of Nazi Germany and significantly altering the course of the war in Europe.

The other events listed (A) The Polish-Soviet War in the early 1920s and (C) The Japanese invasion of the Soviet Union in 1938, while significant in their own right, do not directly vindicate Stalin's speech in the context of his reference to "continual beatings" by foreign powers due to Russia's backwardness:

(A) The Polish-Soviet War was a conflict between two emerging powers and did not involve the exploitation of Russia's backwardness by foreign exploiters as described in Stalin's speech.

(C) The Japanese invasion of 1938, while a significant event, occurred later than Stalin's speech and was more about the Soviet Union's response to Japanese expansionism rather than vindicating Stalin's speech about historical beatings due to backwardness.

Thus, the German invasion of 1941 is the event that most directly aligns with Stalin's speech and the historical context he described, providing a clear example of the consequences of Russia's backwardness and the subsequent struggle to overcome those vulnerabilities.

question:

"Thereupon it was declared by the above-mentioned representatives of the aforesaid King and Queen of Castile, Leon, Aragon, Sicily, Granada, etc., and of the aforesaid King of Portugal and the Algarves, etc.:
[I.] That, whereas a certain controversy exists between the said lords, their constituents, as to what lands, of all those discovered in the ocean sea up to the present day, the date of this treaty, pertain to each one of the said parts respectively; therefore, for the sake of peace and concord, and for the preservation of the relationship and love of the said King of Portugal for the said King and Queen of Castile, Aragon, etc., it being the pleasure of their Highnesses, they, their said representatives, acting in their name and by virtue of their powers herein described, covenanted and agreed that a boundary or straight line be determined and drawn north and south, from pole to pole, on the said ocean sea, from the Arctic to the Antarctic pole. This boundary or line shall be drawn straight, as aforesaid, at a distance of three hundred and seventy leagues west of the Cape Verde Islands, being calculated by degrees, or by any other manner as may be considered the best and readiest, provided the distance shall be no greater than abovesaid. And all lands, both islands and mainlands, found and discovered already, or to be found and discovered hereafter, by the said King of Portugal and by his vessels on this side of the said line and bound determined as above, toward the east, in either north or south latitude, on the eastern side of the said bound provided the said bound is not crossed, shall belong to, and remain in the possession of, and pertain forever to, the said King of Portugal and his successors. And all other lands, both islands and mainlands, found or to be found hereafter, discovered or to be discovered hereafter, which have been discovered or shall be discovered by the said King and Queen of Castile, Aragon, etc., and by their vessels, on the western side of the said bound, determined as above, after having passed the said bound toward the west, in either its north or south latitude, shall belong to, and remain in the possession of, and pertain forever to, the said King and Queen of Castile, Leon, etc., and to their successors."
Treaty of Tordesillas, 1494
Which of the following technologies most directly caused the treaty above to be signed? (A) The compass (B) Germ Theory
pred:
The Treaty of Tordesillas, signed in 1494, was a pivotal agreement between the Catholic monarchs of Spain (Castile and Aragon) and the King of Portugal, primarily addressing the division of newly discovered lands in the Americas. The signing of this treaty was most directly caused by the advent and spread of maritime navigation technologies, particularly the astrolabe, the magnetic compass, and the advances in cartography. These technologies enabled European explorers to venture further out into the Atlantic Ocean, discover new lands, and return home with valuable trade goods, thus sparking a race for territorial claims.

Among the technologies listed:

(A) The compass: The magnetic compass was crucial for navigation across the vast oceans. It allowed sailors to determine their latitude and maintain a consistent course, which was essential for long-distance sea travel and the exploration of new territories.

(B) Germ Theory: While the germ theory of disease, developed much later by scientists like Louis Pasteur, is a significant medical advancement, it had no direct role in the signing of the Treaty of Tordesillas. The treaty was a political and territorial agreement, not a medical one.

Therefore, the technology that most directly caused the treaty to be signed is the compass. It was instrumental in the Age of Discovery, allowing for the exploration and mapping of new lands, which in turn led to the need for a treaty to settle disputes over newly discovered territories.

question:

"I travelled thence to 'Aden, the port of Yemen, on the coast of the ocean. It is surrounded by mountains and can be approached from one side only; it has no crops, trees, or water, but has reservoirs in which rainwater is collected. The Arabs often cut off the inhabitants from their supply of drinking-water until the they buy them off with money and pieces of cloth. It is an exceedingly hot place. It is the port of the Indians, and to it come large vessels from Kinbayat [Cambay], Kawlam [Quilon], Calicut and many other Malabar ports [on the south-west coast of India]. There are Indian merchants living there, as well as Egyptian merchants. Its inhabitants are all either merchants, porters, or fishermen. Some of the merchants are immensely rich, so rich that sometimes a single merchant is sole owner of a large ship with all it contains, and this is a subject of ostentation and rivalry amongst them. In spite of that they are pious, humble, upright, and generous in character, treat strangers well, give liberally to devotees, and pay in full the tithes due to God."
Ibn Battuta, ca. 1325–1354 C.E.
Ibn Battuta's experiences were LEAST similar to the experiences of which of the following? (A) Lorenzo de Medici (B) Xuanzang
pred:
The experiences of Ibn Battuta, a 14th-century Moroccan explorer, and those of Lorenzo de Medici, a 15th-century Italian merchant prince, are fundamentally different in several key aspects. Here's a brief comparison:

**Ibn Battuta:**
- Ibn Battuta was a Muslim traveler who embarked on a 24-year journey across Asia and Africa, covering a distance of over 120,000 kilometers.
- His travels took him through various Islamic and non-Islamic lands, including the Middle East, India, China, and parts of Africa.
- He traveled for a variety of reasons, including to perform the Hajj (pilgrimage to Mecca), seek knowledge, and explore new lands.
- His journey was primarily motivated by religious devotion, curiosity, and a desire to expand his knowledge of the world.
- He documented his travels in a detailed account, the "Rihla" (The Journey), which provides a unique insight into the 14th-century world.

**Lorenzo de Medici:**
- Lorenzo de Medici was a prominent figure in the Italian Renaissance, ruling as de facto ruler of the Florentine Republic from 1469 until his death in 1492.
- His influence was primarily political and economic, as he was a member of the powerful Medici family and played a significant role in the governance of Florence.
- His interests were more focused on art, politics, and patronage, rather than exploration or travel.
- Lorenzo was known for his patronage of the arts, including commissioning works from artists like Michelangelo and Leonardo da Vinci.
- His life was centered around the political and cultural developments of Florence and Italy during the Renaissance.

**Comparison:**
Ibn Battuta's experiences were least similar to those of Lorenzo de Medici because their motivations, activities, and the contexts of their lives were vastly different. Ibn Battuta's travels were driven by religious and exploratory motives, while Lorenzo de Medici's life was characterized by political power, art patronage, and cultural influence within a specific geographic and historical context of Renaissance Italy. Their worlds were separated by religion, culture, and historical epoch, making their experiences fundamentally different.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
"Our constitution does not copy the laws of neighboring states; we are rather a pattern to others than imitators ourselves. Its administration favors the many instead of the few; this is why it is called a democracy. If we look to the laws, they afford equal justice to all in their private differences; if no social standing, advancement in public life falls to reputation for capacity, class considerations not being allowed to interfere with merit; nor again does poverty bar the way, if a man is able to serve the state, he is not hindered by the obscurity of his condition. The freedom which we enjoy in our government extends also to our ordinary life. There, far from exercising a jealous surveillance over each other, we do not feel called upon to be angry with our neighbor for doing what he likes, or even to indulge in those injurious looks which cannot fail to be offensive, although they inflict no positive penalty. But all this ease in our private relations does not make us lawless as citizens. Against this fear is our chief safeguard, teaching us to obey the magistrates and the laws, particularly such as regard the protection of the injured, whether they are actually on the statute book, or belong to that code which, although unwritten, yet cannot be broken without acknowledged disgrace."
Thucydides, History of the Peloponnesian War, ca. 415 B.C.E.
Which of the following correctly describes one of the primary reasons that Greek culture was disseminated widely around the Mediterranean region during the time period represented by the passage? (A) The geography of Greece contains many natural harbors that facilitated trade and commerce. (B) The geography of Greece contains prominent river valleys that facilitated widespread agriculture.
pred:
The correct answer to the question, based on the provided passage from Thucydides' "History of the Peloponnesian War," is (A) The geography of Greece contains many natural harbors that facilitated trade and commerce.

Explanation:
The passage describes the nature of the Greek democracy and how it differs from other systems, emphasizing the principles of meritocracy, equality before the law, and freedom from social and economic barriers to public service. It also highlights the social harmony and respect for law among citizens.

However, the passage does not directly address the reasons for the dissemination of Greek culture around the Mediterranean. It primarily focuses on the internal workings of the Greek state and society.

The correct answer (A) is inferred from the broader context of ancient Greek history and geography. The Greek city-states, due to their numerous natural harbors, were able to engage in extensive trade and maritime activities. This maritime prowess allowed them to spread their culture, ideas, and influence far beyond their borders, through both trade and colonization. The Greeks established numerous colonies throughout the Mediterranean and Black Sea regions, which helped to disseminate their culture, language (Greek), and political ideas (such as democracy) to other peoples.

Option (B) is incorrect because the passage does not mention prominent river valleys or widespread agriculture as reasons for the spread of Greek culture. While agriculture was important in Greece, particularly in the fertile regions like the Peloponnese and Attica, the text does not link this aspect of Greek life to the dissemination of its culture.

Option (C) is not provided in the question, so it cannot be considered as a potential answer.

In summary, the primary reason that Greek culture was disseminated widely around the Mediterranean region during the time period represented by the passage is due to the geography of Greece, which facilitated extensive trade and maritime activities, allowing for the spread of Greek culture through trade, colonization, and cultural exchange.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
"Upon this a question arises: whether it be better to be loved than feared or feared than loved? It may be answered that one should wish to be both, but, because it is difficult to unite them in one person, it is much safer to be feared than loved, when, of the two, either must be dispensed with. Because this is to be asserted in general of men, that they are ungrateful, fickle, false, cowardly, covetous, and as long as you succeed they are yours entirely; they will offer you their blood, property, life, and children, as is said above, when the need is far distant; but when it approaches they turn against you. And that prince who, relying entirely on their promises, has neglected other precautions, is ruined; because friendships that are obtained by payments, and not by greatness or nobility of mind, may indeed be earned, but they are not secured, and in time of need cannot be relied upon; and men have less scruple in offending one who is beloved than one who is feared, for love is preserved by the link of obligation which, owing to the baseness of men, is broken at every opportunity for their advantage; but fear preserves you by a dread of punishment which never fails."
Nicolo Machiavelli, The Prince, ca. 1513 C.E.
Machiavelli's treatise is best understood in the context of which of the following? (A) A time of intense political conflict among warring Italian city-states and other factions (B) A time of collegial cooperation between scholars and ecclesiastical authorities in Italy
pred:
The answer to the question is (A) A time of intense political conflict among warring Italian city-states and other factions.

Explanation:
Nicolo Machiavelli's "The Prince" was written in the early 16th century, specifically around 1513 C.E., during a tumultuous period in Italian history. Italy was fragmented into various city-states, each vying for power, influence, and territorial control. These city-states were often engaged in political intrigue, warfare, and alliances that shifted frequently. The political landscape was characterized by constant battles for supremacy, the rise and fall of different regimes, and the interference of foreign powers such as the French, Spanish, and the Holy Roman Empire.

Machiavelli's treatise was a practical guide for a ruler seeking to maintain and expand power in such a volatile environment. His advice to a prince on whether it is better to be loved or feared was rooted in the harsh realities of Italian politics at the time. Machiavelli argued that in such a setting, it is safer to be feared than loved because love is transient and can easily turn to hatred when circumstances change, whereas fear can be a more reliable means of control. This perspective reflects the brutal and competitive nature of the political climate in which Machiavelli lived and worked. His treatise was not only a commentary on political leadership but also a reflection on the state of Italian politics during his era.

question:
This question refers to the following information.
The passage below is the Chinese emperor's response to English King George III's diplomatic envoys, who were seeking expanded trading privileges (1793).
Strange and costly objects do not interest me. If I have commanded that the tribute offerings sent by you, O King, are to be accepted, this was solely in consideration for the spirit which prompted you to dispatch them from afar. . . . As your Ambassador can see for himself, we possess all things. I set no value on objects strange or ingenious, and have no use for your country's manufactures. It behooves you, O King, to display even greater devotion and loyalty in future, so that, by perpetual submission to our Throne, you may secure peace and prosperity.
How did the Chinese restrict foreign trade during the era 1750–1900? (A) European merchants were confined to a few cities designated for foreign trade. (B) They passed laws intended to persecute and harass foreign residents.
pred: The Chinese restricted foreign trade during the era 1750–1900 primarily through the Canton System, which was in place from 1757 to 1842. This system confined foreign trade to the port of Canton (now Guangzhou) and limited the activities of foreign traders to the Thirteen Factories, a walled compound where they were required to live. Foreigners were not allowed to travel inland, and Chinese officials were not permitted to engage in trade with foreigners outside of these designated areas. Additionally, the Chinese imposed strict regulations on the types of goods that could be traded, the manner in which trade was conducted, and the behavior of foreign residents. This system was designed to control the flow of foreign goods and ideas into China while allowing for some level of economic engagement without fully opening up the Chinese market to foreign influence.

pred:

Women, according to the passage, did not see the expected benefits of the revolution, such as education for their children, indicating that the gains of the revolution were not universally applied or perhaps were not recognized for women.
- Halima Ghomri's interview from the 1970s, after Algeria's war of independence, reflects a similar sentiment. While the war brought freedom from fear and the cessation of war, it did not lead to significant economic improvement for her and other poor peasants. This suggests that the revolution's benefits were not evenly distributed across all segments of society.

Both passages point to the idea that revolutions, while they may bring about significant changes in political and social structures, do not always ensure that these changes are uniformly beneficial to all members of society. This implies that the new liberties gained by revolution can be unevenly distributed or inconsistently applied, leading to the conclusion that revolutions sometimes result in new liberties being enjoyed by some but not by all.

Because this is to be asserted in general of men, that they are ungrateful, fickle, false, cowardly, covetous, and as long as you succeed they are yours entirely; they will offer you their blood, property, life, and children, as is said above, when the need is far distant; but when it approaches they turn against you. And that prince who, relying entirely on their promises, has neglected other precautions, is ruined; because friendships that are obtained by payments, and not by greatness or nobility of mind, may indeed be earned, but they are not secured, and in time of need cannot be relied upon; and men have less scruple in offending one who is beloved than one who is feared, for love is preserved by the link of obligation which, owing to the baseness of men, is broken at every opportunity for their advantage; but fear preserves you by a dread of punishment which never fails."
Nicolo Machiavelli, The Prince, ca. 1513 C.E.
Which of the following best characterizes the author's attitude in the passage? (A) Cynicism about the loyalty of a ruler's subjects (B) Ambivalence about the future of his economic prospects
pred:
The author's attitude in the passage is best characterized as (A) cynicism about the loyalty of a ruler's subjects. 

Niccolò Machiavelli, in "The Prince," discusses the nature of power and leadership, advising rulers on how to maintain control. He presents a very pragmatic view of human nature, suggesting that people are generally ungrateful, fickle, false, cowardly, covetous, and unreliable. Machiavelli argues that while it is ideal to be both loved and feared, it is safer to be feared because fear is more reliable and less likely to be betrayed. He emphasizes that the loyalty of subjects is conditional and that they will often turn against a leader when it is most dangerous, often due to their own self-interest. This cynical view of human nature and the unreliability of loyalty is what best characterizes Machiavelli's attitude in the passage.

question:

To consent to the consignment year after year of hundreds of innocent victims to a cruel and untimely end, when the power exists of preventing it, is a predicament which no conscience can contemplate without horror. But, on the other hand, to put to hazard by a contrary course the very safety of the British Empire in India is an alternative which itself may be considered a still greater evil. When we had powerful neighbours and greater reason to doubt our own security, expediency might recommend a more cautious proceeding, but now that we are supreme my opinion is decidedly in favour of an open and general prohibition.
William Bentinck, Govenor-General of India, "On the Suppression of Sati," 1829
I have made it my study to examine the nature and character of the Indians [who trade with us], and however repugnant it may be to our feelings, I am convinced they must be ruled with a rod of iron, to bring and keep them in a proper state of subordination, and the most certain way to effect this is by letting them feel their dependence on [the foodstuffs and manufactured goods we sell them].
George Simpson, Head of Northern Department, Hudson's Bay Company, 1826
The passages above are best understood in the context of which of the following practices? (A) Exercise of colonial administrative power over native peoples (B) Mobilization of military resources from colonial possessions
pred:
The passages above refer to the practices of colonial administration and the control of trade with native peoples in India. Specifically, they discuss the decisions made by William Bentinck, the Governor-General of India, and George Simpson, the Head of the Northern Department of the Hudson's Bay Company, regarding the practices of sati (widow burning) and the control of trade with Indian traders, respectively.

William Bentinck's statement addresses the practice of sati, which involved the immolation of a widow on her husband's funeral pyre. Bentinck expresses his horror at the continued practice of sati and argues that it is the responsibility of the British Empire to prevent such a cruel and inhumane tradition. He believes that to continue this practice is a grave evil that the British must stop, as they have the power to do so.

George Simpson's statement reflects the attitudes of colonial administrators towards the Indian traders. Simpson suggests that the Indian traders must be ruled with an iron hand to maintain their subordination. He believes that the best way to achieve this is by controlling the supply of essential goods like foodstuffs and manufactured goods that the Indians depend on. This approach is part of the broader colonial strategy to exert control over the economic activities of the colonized people and ensure their dependency on the colonial powers.

In summary, the passages are best understood in the context of the exercise of colonial administrative power over native peoples and the control of trade with them. This includes the suppression of cultural practices deemed harmful by the colonial authorities (as in the case of sati) and the manipulation of trade to maintain colonial dominance.
